section: 9 Extension: Mathematical operations across multiple lines
text:
9 Extension: Mathematical operations across multiple lines
If you have a long mathematical formula to execute in code, there is a good chance that you will want to break the code up into multiple lines.
Â 
To keep it simple, letâ€™s add 5 values together across multiple lines:
c = 10 + 10 + 10 +
    10 + 10;
If you put the above code in you script, then you will get c = 50 in the Environment.
Â 
However, this code:
d = 10 + 10 + 10
    + 10 + 10;
will put d=30 in the Environment.
Â 
This is because R did not know the continue the equation for d to the second line.Â  R treated the first line as the complete command/equation.Â  By putting the ( + ) at the end of the first line for c, R knew it needed to continue the command to the next line.
Â 
By the way, R does do something with the second line for d â€“ it prints the answer to Console if you click Run:
> d = 10 + 10 + 10
>     + 10 + 10;
[1] 20
In other words:
+ 10 + 10
is a command that evaluates to 20

title: 1-03: Mathematical Operations
text:
10 Traps: Forgetting Multiplication Symbol
Letâ€™s say you are solving for kinetic energy:
\[
E_{k}=\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}
\]
And you have a value for velocity (v) and mass (m)
rm(list=ls());          # clean out the environment

m = 100;
v = 10;
Â«KE = ????;    # should be: KE = (1/2)*m*v^2;Â»
If you code KE like this::
KE = 1/2*mv^2;
Then you will get the error: object â€˜mvâ€™ not found in the Console tab because R does not realize you want to multiply the variables m and v, it thinks you are trying to use a variable named mv, and the variable mv does not exist.
Â 
If you code KE like this::
KE = (1/2)m*v^2;  # same error arises if you do 1/2m*v^2
you will get the error: unexpected symbol (FigureÂ 7) and the Console tab will point to the m






FigureÂ 7: Unexpected symbol error



Â 
In this case, R is expecting an operation (symbol) after (1/2).Â  m is a variable, not a operation, hence the error.

section: 11 Trap: Units, or lack thereof, in programming

title: 1-03: Mathematical Operations
text:
12 Extension: The show.error.location line
The second line of code in FigureÂ 1 tells R to provide a line number where an error occurs:
options(show.error.locations = TRUE);
In FigureÂ 1, in the Console tab the error includes the line number, 9, because of the line above. This seems like a great idea except that this line only works in a few limited situations. As you get into more complex code, this line will not work and R will not show you the line number for the error.
Â 
Unfortunately, R is one of the harder programming languages to debug. We will get to some debugging strategies in later lessons. For now, you can include the show.error.location line in your code. It does not hurt â€“ it just has limited utility.

text:
3 Viewing file extensions and hidden files
By default, Windows and Mac hides file extensions from you (e.g., your Word document file is listed in the file manager as stuff instead of stuff.docx).Â  This is not convenient when you are programming as you are working with many file types (e.g., *.txt, *.r, *.csv) and, many times, the only difference between the name of two files is the extension.Â  For instance, you might have two files called weather.r and weather.csv in your folder â€“ without file extensions they are both listed as weather.
Â 
Also, when you are programming, there are files you will need to access that are hidden by default by the operating system.
Â 
This section is optional, but I would highly recommend you learn how to view all files and file extensions â€“ it will greatly assist you when programming.

3.1 Viewing in newer versions of Windows 11
This is easy to to do in newer versions of Windows 11:

Open the File Explorer
Click View -> Show
Check File name extensions and Hidden items







FigureÂ 1: Change settings to view all file extensions on Windows 11





3.2 Viewing in Windows 10 and older Windows 11 versions
This feature is a bit buried in these Window versions.
Â 

Open any File Explorer window (i.e., your folder viewer)
In menu bar

Windows 10: click View -> Options -> Change folder and search options
Windows 11: click 3 dots ( Â· Â· Â· ) -> Options

In Folder Options window (FigureÂ 2), go to the View tab
Uncheck Hide extensions for known file types
Check Show hidden files, folder, and drives
Click OK







FigureÂ 2: Viewing in older versions of Windows





3.3 Viewing in Mac
File Extensions:

OpenÂ Finder
Click on Finder -> Preferencesâ€¦
In Finder Preferences window click on the Advanced tab
Check Show all filename extensions

Â 
Hidden files:

You can temporarily see hidden files in the Finder by pressing Command-Shift-Dot ( . ).Â 
You can use the Terminal to permanently show hidden files as described on this webpage but this is not recommended unless you are comfortable with Terminal commands.







FigureÂ 3: Change settings to view all file extensions on a Mac

text:
4 Install R and RStudio on your computer
We are going to install R and RStudio on your computer. R is a programming language and RStudio provides a structured environment for the R programming language, similar to the way Microsoft Word provides a structured environment for document editing. RStudio is patterned on other popular programming environments like Microsoftâ€™s Visual Studio.
Â 
On Windows the default installation can be used for R and RStudio. For Mac, installation is a bit trickier â€“ details below.
Â 
Note: Even if you already have the software installed, it is a good idea to verify you have a recent version.

4.1 Install or update R (need version 4.4 or higher)
The R for Windows download is here. Click on Download R 4.#.# for Windows.
Â 
TheÂ R for Mac download is here. Â 

There are two versions of R for MacÂ 

R-4.#.#-arm64.pkg: for Macs with Apple-based processors (M1, M2, M3â€¦), all Macs from 2021 on use Apple-based processors
R-4.#.#.pkg: for older Macs with Intel-based processors

The installer will tell you If you pick the wrong pkg file â€“ there is no harm except a bit of wasted time.

Â 
And for those of you using Linux â€“ theÂ R for Linux download instructions are here.


4.2 Install or update RStudio
You need version 2023.12 or higher for this class and you should have 2025.04 or higher if you are using Git.
Â 
You can download the RStudio Installer here. Download the appropriate file for your computer under Installers, open the file, and use the default installation options.

4.2.1 Special instructions for Mac users
For Mac users there are some extra complexities:

You might be asked to install Command Line Developer Tools while installing RStudio. Go ahead and install the developer tools.
Â 
The download for RStudio is called RStudio-202X.XX.dmg.Â  Double-clicking the file will open the window below (FigureÂ 4).Â  In the window, drag the RStudio file to the Applications folder







FigureÂ 4: Opening RStudio DMG file



If you already have RStudio installed, you will be asked if you want to replace the old version â€“ go ahead and Replace it.

After installation, unmount the RStudio device in the Finder by clicking the eject button (FigureÂ 5)

5 Installing a package
GGPlot2, is a widely used package that does not come with R or RStudio â€“ so we are going to install the GGPlot2 package using RStudio.
Â 
To install the package GGPlot2 using RStudio (FigureÂ 6):

Click Tools -> Install Packagesâ€¦

Most of the work you will do in R involves multiple scripts, data files, and perhaps other types of files.Â  All these files together make up your project and they exist within a Project Folder, which is the folder on your computer than contains all the files and subfolders for your project â€“ and it is very important that you keep all files associated with a project within a Project Folder.
Â 
In this class we will be using RStudio to create, edit, and execute R scripts.Â  In RStudio, there is a feature called RStudio Projects, which is a Project Folder, that makes it much easier to move, share, and host your project on GitHub.Â  You need to keep all of your class work in an RStudio Project.

section: 12 Extension: Working directories in R and RStudio (why RStudio Projects)
text:
12 Extension: Working directories in R and RStudio (why RStudio Projects)
This topic is, in this authorâ€™s opinion, one of the most frustrating topic in R.Â  Compared to other programming languages (e.g., C++. Python, Javascript), R handling of working directories makes it harderto share projects.
Â 
A working directory is the folder location used when one file is looking for another file.Â  It is best shown by its use-case: a script file that is reading in information from another file â€“ this file can be a data file or another script file.
Â 
For example, letâ€™s say we have a script file called weather.r and it is pulling in data from the file weather2020.csv.Â  weather.r needs to first find the folder location for weather2020.csv before it can access the file.Â  To do this, weather.r needs a path to weather2020.csv.Â  This path can be thought of as map directions between two points â€“ and the working directory is the starting point.
Â 
For the vast majority of programming languages, there is no concept of a working directory.Â  The process of files calling other files works like google maps â€“ a route is specified between the two files starting with the folder the caller (e.g., weather.r) is in and ending where the callee (e.g., weather.csv) is. The path between the two files is called a relative file path.Â 

12.1 Râ€™s default handling of working directories
In R, the starting point, or working directory, is fixed for all R files opened in a session (called a session variable).Â  Using the google maps analogy, this is like saying the map starting point is fixed for everyone â€“ it does not matter where you actually are located.Â  You can change the working directory in your script using setwd() but this changes the working directories for all R files in the session.Â  In other words, you are simply changing the starting point to a new location and all files will now use that location.


12.2 Absolute file paths (a bad fix to the problem)
One way to get around working directories is to use an absolute file path.Â  So, instead of mapping between weather.R and weather.csv, you just give the file path for weather.csv on your computer (called the absolute file path).
Â 
This will look something like: c:\Users\RStudent\Documents\WeatherProj\Data\weather.csv
Â 
Doing this means you do not have to worry about working directories.Â  But this solution breaks as soon as you move files on your computer or move them to another computer.Â  The reason is that the file path changes.Â  Absolute file paths make it almost impossible to share file and should not be used.


12.3 How RStudio Projects handle working directory (the least-worst option)
An RStudio Project sets the working directory to the Project Folder.Â  So, for weather.r to find weather.csv inside an RStudio Project, it just needs to know where weather.csv is located relative to the project folder.Â  Most likely this will be something like: Data\weather.csv. This makes it far easier to share your project because the path to weather.csv will be the same on any computer.
While I believe this is by far the best method for handling working directory issues, it comes with a major caveat:You need to open script files from within the RStudio Project.Â  Opening the project sets the working directory for all script files used in the session.Â  If you a file outside of the Project session, then the working directory is not set by the project.


12.4 The default working directory
A working directory is not defined for a file, it is defined for a session.Â  So, all files within that session will have the same working directory.Â  IF you change the working directory in one file, you change it for every file within the session.Â  This leads to awkward behavior where one R file can change the behavior of another R file within the same session by using setwd().

title: 1-01: RStudio Projects Setup
text:
15 Extension: Run vs.Â Source
Technically speaking, the difference between Run and Source is:

Source will execute all the code in a script file.
Run will execute either:

The code that is highlighted (if code is highlighted) OR
The command that the cursor is on (if the command is on more than one line) OR
The whole line the cursor is on


Â 
The real difference lies in a historical discussion of scripting vs.Â programming, which is a discussion beyond this class.Â  Suffice to say, R was originally intended to be more like an advanced calculator than a programming language. The script files would contain multiple lines of code that could be execute independently and in any order (think of these as buttons on a calculator).Â  The user could click a â€œbuttonâ€ to pull in data, click another â€œbuttonâ€ to run statistical analysis on the data, and click a third â€œbuttonâ€ to output the analysis.Â  This is what the Run button does.
Â 
However, as R has grown, the focus has shifted towards developing well-structured code just like any modern programming language (e.g., Python, C, Java).Â This means executing the script as a whole instead of in parts.Â  This is what Source does.Â  Executing your script as a whole instead of in parts has many advantages as the code is easier to debug, easier to share, and much better organized â€“ because you are forced to organize it. In the not-so-humble opinion of this author, learning to treat your script as a whole is a vital part of learning how to program.Â  For this reason, we will always be using the Source button in this class.

title: 1-01: RStudio Projects Setup
section: 16 Extension: Create a standalone R script
text:
16 Extension: Create a standalone R script
There are two ways to create script file in RStudio:

A standalone script
As part of an RStudio Project

Â 
Many people use the first method.Â  In this class we exclusively use the second method.Â  The first method of creating a script file is fine for testing something out.Â  The second method is far better for organizing larger projects and sharing your code with others.
Â 
The reason the second method is better is because a project consist of many file that need to talk each-other.Â  Script files will call other scripts file or read in data from data files.Â  In order to makes this work, the script files need to know how to find the other files. In an RStudio Project, this is easy because the working directory is always the Project Folder of your project â€“ and all files in the project are contained within the Project Folder.Â  So, you just need to look for the file relative to the Project Folder.
Â 
R Programmers often get around the lack of a Project Folder/defined working directory by setting the working directory in code using setwd().Â  This can work locally but becomes problematic when files are shared or moved.Â  Whereas, RStudio Project always maintain their folder structure.

title: Introduction and Syllabus
text:
The purpose of this class is to introduce students to the principles of programming using R and RStudio.Â  R and RStudio are powerful and versatile data analysis packages that are freely available. The R community is extensive and is constantly developing new tools that rival and, in many cases, surpass commercial statistical software and graphing packages.Â  This class is designed for students new to programming.Â  While the class focus is on R programming in RStudio, the programming skills taught (e.g., for loops, if-else statements, functions) are designed so that students can transfer their skills to other programming languages like C, JavaScript, or Python.

title: Introduction and Syllabus
text:
3 Class Structure
The course has 28 lessons divided into two units:Â Basic Programming and Data Programming
Â 

Basic Programming: basic programming structures and operations like variables, inputs, outputs, mathematical operations, if-else structures, for loops, and conditional operations.

1-1 RStudio Projects Setup: Set up a Project in RStudio and learn the basics of the RStudio programming environment.
1-2 Variables: Discussion of the different types of variables, variable naming conventions, assigning values to variables, changing values.
1-3 Mathematical Operations: Mathematical operations on numeric variables, power operations, algebraic formulas in R
1-4 Vectors and Data Frames: Learn about CSV files and two common data types in R
1-5 Functions Introduction: Reading function descriptions and using arguments
1-6 Run and Source: The two ways in R to execute a script and some convenient coding feature in RStudio
1-7 Outputs: Output information to the console, mixed string, and numeric outputs.
1-8 Conditional Operators: Creating decision points in your script usingÂ if() statements and the six conditional operators.
1-9 If-Else Statements: Checking multiple conditions on a variable, creating error conditions.
1-10 For loops: Cycle through data using for loops and performing conditional operations on each value
1-11 For loops and State Variables: Remembering values as you cycle through for loops
1-12 Multiple Conditions: Checking complex conditions on a variable using logical operators & and
1-13 Functions: Creating your own function, adding and using arguments and return valuesÂ 
1-14 Function 2: Default arguments, multiple returns, error checking
1-15 Nested Loops and Matrices: for loops within for loops and multidimensional vectors

Data Programming: data programming structures and operations like file inputs, vectors, subset operations, plotting, and data types.

2-1 GGPlot Introduction: Structures within GGPlot, creating basic plots from data in a data frame
2-2 Data frame Modifications: Add, remove, and reorder column in a data frame, and manipulating string values
2-3 Data types and Data Frames: Conversion between data types, NA values, common issues with data frames
2-4 Which Statements: Conditionally subset numeric data, plot subsetted data
2-5 Which and Regular Expressions: Conditionally subset string data, finding patterns in string valuesÂ 
2-6 Datetime Objects: Formatted date and datetime values, converting from strings to datetime valueÂ 
2-7 Matrices: Create two-dimensional data, performing statistics on 2D data
2-8 Binding and Sampling: Combining data and creating randomly sampled values
2-9 Stacking and Mapping: Plotting multiple columns in a data frame at once, mapping data to color and size
2-10 Statistical Tests: t-tests, ANOVAs, linear regressions and storing and reading information from the testsÂ 
2-11 Objects and Attributes: deeper dive into the data types in R and their attributes
2-12 Lists: Reading, navigating, subsetting, and creating List objects in RÂ 
2-13 Breakpoints: a method for debugging your codeÂ 



3.1 Lesson Application
All lessons have anÂ Application section at the end that will ask you to apply what you learned in the lesson in your own script. The Application is the only product that gets evaluated. There are no tests and there is no final exam.
Â 
The class is self-paced, however you should not go more than 2 weeks without handing in an application unless you inform the instructor that there will be a delay.Â  You will have a chance to redo all applications.


3.2 Lesson feedback
Each application has these three questions regarding the lesson:

What was your level of comfort with the lesson/application?
What areas of the lesson/application confused or still confuses you?
What are some things you would like to know more about that is related to, but not covered in, this lesson?

3.3 Extensions and Traps
Many of the lessons contain optional content called Extension and Traps.Â  Extensions contain material that goes beyond the lessonâ€™s objectives and Traps capture some of the common issues students have with the lessonâ€™s objectives.Â  There are links to Extensions and Traps within the Content area of the lesson.Â  Clicking on the appropriate link takes you directly to the Extension or Trap. text:
2 Questions about the materialâ€¦
If you have any questions about the material in this lesson, feel free to email them to the instructor, Charlie Belinsky, at belinsky@msu.edu.

title: 1-02: Variables
text:
3 Programming structures
In all programming languages there are basically 4 main structures that cover almost every aspect of programming:

Variables: named storage area for values used in the script
If-Else Statements: conditional execution of code
For Loops: execution of code a fixed number of times
Functions: place to store commonly used code

Â 
We will go through all 4 of these in the class and in the lesson we will cover the first, Variables.

title: 1-02: Variables
text:
4 Different types of variables
Variables is a widely used term found in many different fields, and its definition is not consistent across the fields.Â  In this class, when I say variable I am referring to a programming variable. When I am referring to a variable in another field, I will add the field to the term variable (e.g., algebraic variable, experimental variable, statistical variable).

4.1 Algebraic variables
In Physics, we use algebraic variables to describe the relationship between physical properties.Â  For example, velocity can be expressed algebraically asÂ  v=d/t where v, d, and t are symbols representing the physical properties of velocity, distance, and time.Â  The formula states that the relationship v=d/t is always maintained even as the individual values change.
Â 
In this case, v, d, and t are all algebraic variables that have the following properties:

Name: v, d, t (name is synonymous with symbol)
Type: numeric (v, d, and t are all numbers)
Value: given by situation â€“ the value can be known or unknown



4.2 Variables in programming
In programming, variables work in a similar way. Variables in programming are named storage locations in memory that hold information.
Â 
This information could be

a runnerâ€™s distance, time, and velocity
the number of fish caught in a day
the name of the lake the fish were caught in
weather information such as temperature, humidity, or wind speed

Â 
Like algebraic variables, variables in programming have a name, type, and value.

4.2.1 Name
The name corresponds to the symbol in our physics example above â€“ it is how the variable is represented in the script.Â  The name is used to reference the storage location in memory that holds the value.Â  For our initial example, we will use v, d, and t as the variable names.Â  Later in this lesson, I will talk about variable naming conventions.


4.2.2 ValueÂ 
The value is the information that is stored in the location pointed to by the name, so when v = 10 , that means there is a storage location in memory named v, and in that location, there is the number 10. Note: we will worry about units later.
Â 
Trap: Constant variables in R


4.2.3 Type
The type describes what kind of value is being stored in memory which, in turn, tells R what kind of operations can be performed on the variable. Distance, velocity, and time all have numeric values, and mathematical operations can be performed on them.
Â 
Numeric is one type of value a variable can have, some of the other types of values are:

strings (also called characters): a text value (e.g., a lake name)
categorical: a limited set of text values (e.g., the four seasons or the five Great Lakes)
Boolean: a TRUE/FALSE statement
Date: a date in day-month-year format

Â 
We will talk more about the non-numeric variable types in future lessons, for now, we will stick with numeric variables.

title: 1-02: Variables
text:
5 Using variables in a script
We are going to create a simple script that calculates velocity given distance and time.
Â 
There are three variables in this script: d, v, and t
Â 
The steps for making this script are:

Open Your RStudio Project (or create one if you do not have one)
Open a new script file
Add code to the script
Execute (Source) the code


5.1 Open your RStudio Project
It would be best to use the same RStudio Project for the whole class and you can use the one you created in the last lesson.
Â 
There are multiple ways to open an RStudio Project:

Open your Project Folder in a file manager and double-click the *.proj file, where * is the name of your project
In RStudio, click File -> Open Projectâ€¦ -> navigate to your Project Folder and click the *.proj file
In RStudio, click File -> Recent Projects -> choose the RStudio Project
Use the Projects dropdown menu in the top-right corner of RStudio (FigureÂ 1)







FigureÂ 1: The Project dropdown menu in RStudio â€“ something I use all the time!





5.2 Open a new script file
Inside your RStudio Project, click on File -> New File -> R Script (FigureÂ 2) .Â  An empty file named Untitled1 will appear as a tab in the File Editor window.Â  Save the file as lesson1-02.r in your script folder.
Â 
Note: you should always name and save a script file before editing it. Do not leave it as Untitled1






FigureÂ 2: Opening a new R file in RStudio





5.3 Add code to the script
Copy and paste the following lines into the code window and click the Source button in the bar above the code (or click Code -> Source):
rm(list=ls());    # Clear out the Environment     
  
# create two variables: d and t and give them values
d = 100;
t = 20;
# create a variable v that is calculated using d and t
v = d/t;
Lines 1 cleans out the Environment tab (top-right corner) each time the script is executed.Â  This provides you with a clean slate each time you run a script and I put this line at the top of most of my scripts.
Extension: Why clear the Environment tab?
Â 
Line 1 also has an inline comment that starts with #. Everything after the # is informational and does not get executed.
Â 
Lines 3 and 6Â are full comment lines â€“ again, they are informational and there to make the script easier to understand.Â  You can take them out and the script will produce the same result.
Â 
Lines 4, 5, and 7 are where the real action occurs and each line contains a variable assignment:

Line 4 assigns the value 100 to the variable named d
Line 5 assigns the value 20 to the variable named t
Line 7Â assigns the value of the calculation d/t to the variable named v.

Â 
Lines 1, 4, 5,Â andÂ 7Â all have semicolons ( ; ) at the end.Â  The semicolon designates the end of a programming command just like the period designates the end of a sentence.Â  The semicolon is optional in R and is often not used, but I highly recommend the use of semicolons in all of your scripts. Semicolons allow for more flexibility (e.g., you can put multiple â€œsentencesâ€ on one line), help you think about the flow of your code, and are required in many programming languages.
Â 
Trap: Assignment vs.Â Equality Operations
Extension: alternate assignment operator


5.4 Execute your code â€“ the Environment tab
Click Source to execute your R code ( FigureÂ 3 ).Â  Your RStudio window should look similar to this:






FigureÂ 3: Executing (sourcing) the velocity-distance-time script



Notice that the Environment tab displays the values for the variables v, d, and t. The Environment tab displays every variable in your script and is a very useful tool for viewing the results of your script and for debugging when things go wrong..
Â 
Try changing the values for d and t (lines 7 and 8) and click Source again to see how the values in the Environment tab change.

5.4.1 The Unexpected end of document error
In FigureÂ 3 there is a red x on the last line indicating an error. The error says unexpected end of document. This is not a real problem, it will not cause any issues with your script. It is a bug in how RStudio deals with semicolons. You can remove the last semicolon if you want to get rid of the error.

title: 1-02: Variables
text:
6 Re-assigning values to variables
Variables get their namesake from the fact that their values can change.
Â 
In the code below:

d is assigned the value 100 in line 5
d to used to calculate v in line 7
d is assigned a new value of 400 in line 8

Â 
Source the code below to see what happens
rm(list=ls());    # Clear out the Environment    
  
# create three variables: d, t, and v
# give d and t values and use them to calculate v
d = 100;   # assign d the value 100
t = 20;
v = d/t;   # use d to calculate v

d = 400;   # re-assigns d to 400
In the Environment tab the value of v remains 5 even though d changes.Â 






FigureÂ 4: Changing d in the script does not retroactively change v



The value of v remains 5 because line 7 assigns the current valueof d/t to v. But, as of line 9, d is still equal to 100. v does not get updated because one of the variables used to calculate it (in this case, d) changes afterwards. The script runs in order, and variables are not updated retroactively.
Â 
In other words, v will remain 5 until it is explicitly assigned another value.
Â 
Trap: Assigning nonexistent variables

6.1 Reassigning values to a variable
What happens if you add the lineÂ v=d/t at the end of the script? Try the following code and click Source
rm(list=ls());    # Clear out the Environment    
  
# create three variables: d, t, and v
# give d and t values and use them to calculate v
d = 100; # assign d the value 100
t = 20;
v = d/t; # use d to calculate v

d = 400; # re-assigns d to 400
v = d/t; # re-assign v using the new value of d
Notice that now the value of v has changed.Â  This is because line 10 assigns a new value to v calculated using the value of d from line 9.






FigureÂ 5: Assign a new value to v after assigning the new value to d

title: 1-02: Variables
text:
7 In-line and whole-line comments
The code in the previous script (FigureÂ 5) has examples of whole-line comments (lines 3 and 4) and in-line comments (lines 5, 7, 9, and 10 ).Â  R ignores everything after the ( # ) but still executes everything on the line before the ( # ).Â  In-line comments are a nice way to give a quick description of the code on a line, whereas whole-line comments are better for more robust descriptions â€“ especially when code get complicated.

title: 1-02: Variables
text:
8 Naming variables
The problem with variable names like v, d, and t is that they are not very descriptive.Â  It is good programming practice to give names that are descriptive so that people reading your code can more easily understand what is going on.Â 
Â 
The first step would be to spell the variable names out, for example:Â velocity, distance, and time.
Â 
However, a script solving for velocity will probably be calculating multiple velocities.Â  Perhaps the script is calculating the velocity of both a runner and a car â€“ the variable names should reflect this.Â 

8.1 Naming Rules
There are a few rules for naming a variable:

It must start with a letter
It can only contain letters, numbers, or the underscore ( _ )

dots ( . ) are also accepted in R but dots are not accepted in most programming languages
this means no spaces!

There are system reserved words you cannot use as variable names (e.g., if, else, for, while, TRUE, FALSE, function, nextâ€¦).Â  We will learn what these reserved words mean in future lessons.



8.2 Naming Conventions
There are two common programming conventions for variables names:

Capitalize the first letter of every word except the first: runnerVelocity, runnerDistance, runnerTime
Put an underscore ( _ ) between each word:Â  runner_velocity, runner_distance, runner_time

Â 
Trap: Case counts in variable names
Â 
For all your class work, you need to use these two conventions.Â  I will use the first convention in most of my examples.
Â 
Note: R programmers often use dots in variable names: runner.velocity, runner.distance.Â  I do not recommend this as this method will not work in most other programming languages.

title: 1-02: Variables
text:
9 Application
Two runners run a 400 meter race.Â 
The first runner takes 127 seconds, the second runner takes 140 seconds.
Â 
Write a script that:

Calculates each runnerâ€™s speed in meters/second
Calculates each runnerâ€™s speed in miles/hour

3600 seconds = 1 hour
1609 meters = 1 mile


So, the script will calculate 4 velocities in all.
Â 
Make sure you use variables for all values and follow proper variable naming convention.
Â 
After your Source the script, make sure you can see all of the variables, with the correct answer, in the Environment tab.
Â 
Save the script asÂ app1-02.r in yourÂ scripts folder andÂ  email your Project Folder to Charlie Belinsky at belinsky@msu.edu.
Â 
Instructions for zipping the Project Folder are here.
Â 
If you have any questions regarding this application, feel free to email them to Charlie Belinsky at belinsky@msu.edu.

9.1 Questions to answer
Answer the following in comments inside your application script:

What was your level of comfort with the lesson/application?
What areas of the lesson/application confused or still confuses you?
What are some things you would like to know more about that is related to, but not covered in, this lesson?



9.2 Challenge
Use random values for the times instead of 127 and 140.Â  The easiest way to get a random number in R is to use the sample() function:
Â 
Examples:
randomNum1 = sample(x=10:20, size=1);  # number between 10 and 20 (inclusive)
randomNum2 = sample(x=-5:5, size=1);   # number between -5 and 5 (inclusive)

title: 1-02: Variables
text:
10 Trap: Assignment vs.Â Equality Operations
The equal sign ( = ) plays a different role in programming than in Algebra.
Â 
In algebra, the equal sign is an equality operator saying that the two sides are equivalent to each other.

So, in algebra, v = d/t says that v is equivalent to d divided by t
The algebraic variable v will change if d or t changes

Â 
In programming, the equals sign is an assignment operator and it says that the variable on the left side will be assigned the value calculated on the right side.

So, in programming, v = d/t says that v will be assigned the calculation ofÂ  d divided by t
In this case,Â v will not change if d or t changes (unless v is explicitly reassigned after d or t changes).Â  Once assigned, the value of v is independent of the variables used in the calculations.


10.1 Treating the equal sign as an equality operation
A very common error in programming is to treat the assignment operator ( =) as an equality operator.
Â 
The following statements make sense in algebra as equality statementsÂ but will cause errors in R.
# d/2 is not a valid variable, you cannot "assign" a value to "d/2"
# d = 100*2 is valid
d/2 = 100; 

# 20 cannot be assigned the value of 't' 
# t = 20 is valid
20 = t;  

# d/t is not a valid variable 
# v = d/t is valid
d/t = v;
Put the above lines of code in your script individually.Â  You will notice an error message gets displayed in the Console tab.Â  The error messages are often unintuitive.
Â 
In the following example (FigureÂ 6), line 9 contains an error and the lines below it never gets executed:
rm(list=ls());
# this code sometimes gives the line number of an error
options(show.error.locations = TRUE);  

# create three variables: d, t, and v
# give d and t values and use them to calculate v
d = 100;
20 = t;   # error!
v = d/t;  # this line will not be executed






FigureÂ 6: Assignment error in the R Script



Notice that the execution of the script stops as soon as an error occurs â€“ so, in this case, line 10, which calculates v, never gets executed.

title: 1-02: Variables
text:
11 Trap: Constant variables in R
There are mathematical constants like Ï€ that should never change, and R has a predefined variable named pi that is equal to 3.1415.Â  In other words, there is a storage location in R referred to as pi that contains the numeric value 3.1415. The problem is that pi is technically a variable in R and can be changed.
Â 
Source the following code in a new script file:
rm(list=ls());

a = pi;  # pi is a predefined constant in R
pi = 3;  # But, R let's you reassign a value to pi
b = pi;  # And now there is going to be a problem
And you will see that you can reassign the value of pi in R. Most programming langauges will give an error if you tried to do this.

title: 1-02: Variables
text:
12 Trap: Assigning nonexistent variables
The first time you assign a value to a variable, a storage container is created in memory and a value is put in it.Â  We call this a declaration (more about declarations later). After a variable has been declared, it can be used in calculations and re-assigned values.Â  Before a variable is declared, R knows nothing about the variable.
Â 
Here is an example of using a variable before it is declared.Â Note: the only change in this script was moving the line v=d/t before the declaration of d and t:
rm(list=ls());             
# gives the line number of the error
options(show.error.locations = TRUE);
  
# create three variables: d, t, and v
# give d and t values and use them to calculate v
v = d/t;   # error, d and t have not been declared
d = 100; 
t = 20;
If you Source this code in a new script file, you will get an error in the Console tab that says object â€˜dâ€™ not found. The reason for this error is that, on line 7, the script is asked to assign the calculation d/t to the variable v butÂ d and t do not exist yet.
Â 
Try the following code and see how the error changes. Notice in this code v=d/t is after the declaration of d but before the declaration of t.
rm(list=ls());             
# gives the line number of the error
options(show.error.locations = TRUE);

# create three variables: d, t, and v
# give d and t values and use them to calculate v
d = 100;
v = d/t;  # error
t = 20;

title: 1-02: Variables
section: 13 Trap: Case counts in variable names
text:
13 Trap: Case counts in variable names
In R, as in most scripting languages, uppercase and lowercase letters are seen as different.Â  So, runnersTime and runnerstime are seen by R as two different variable names.Â  If the case is not correct, then you will receive an Object not found error just like you would if you spelled the variable name wrong.

title: 1-02: Variables
text:
14 Extension: alternate assignment operator
In R, there are two assignment operators, the equal sign ( = ) and the arrow ( <- ).Â 
rm(list=ls());    # Clear out the Environment  
  
d <- 100;   # same as d = 100
t <- 20;    # same as t = 20
v <- d/t;   # same = d/t
You will see a lot of R programs written using the arrow.Â  In this class, I will use the equal sign because that is the standard for most other programming languages (including JavaScript and C) and it is easier to type.Â  You can use either operator in your scripts in this class.
Â 
For assigning values to a variable, ( <- ) and ( = ) are functionally equivalent. There is a difference between the two operators when working with functions, which we will cover when we get to function.

title: 1-02: Variables
section: 15 Extension: Why clear the Environment tab?
text:
15 Extension: Why clear the Environment tab?
This is kind of an advanced topic but there are many people who come to this class having already done some R programming and it is most likely they never clear the Environment when running scripts. This means that variables are persistent and will still be around when another script is executed.
Â 
This, in general, is a bad programming practice, which I will talk more about in future lessons. If a script needs a variable from another script then you want the first script to call the second script. This kind of explicit programming makes sharing and debugging your scripts a lot easier.

title: 1-04: Vectors and Data Frames
section: 2 Standalone scripts vs.Â scripts within a Project
text:
2 Standalone scripts vs.Â scripts within a Project
In the last two lessons, everything we did was contained to one script file â€“ no outside file was needed.Â  The scripts in those lessons were standalone scripts and could be executed inside or outside your RStudio Project with the same results.
Â 
Standalone scripts are rare and are generally only created for testing purposes.
Â 
The script for this lesson will not execute correctly if it is treated as a standalone script (e.g., it is executed outside of the RStudio Project).Â This is because the file looks for a data file and it needs to know where to look for the data file.

2.1 Set Working Directory (a cautionary statement)
Many people still treat all R scripts as standalone scripts (i.e., they do not use RStudio Project). This causes all sorts of problems when script file look for other files.Â  The old way to get around this is to set the Working Directories using setwd().Â  This is a mess because Working Directories change when file are moved between computers or even within a computer.Â  Scripts that set working directories are much harder to share and maintain.Â  This author strongly suggests that you use RStudio Projects and avoid the working directory mess.

title: 1-04: Vectors and Data Frames
text:
3 Vector Variables
Vector variables, or vector for short, are variables that hold multiple related values.Â  For instance if we have temperature values for 5 days, we could create 5 variables and assign each one a temperature value:
tempHigh1 = 65;
tempHigh2 = 57;
tempHigh3 = 61;
tempHigh4 = 64;
tempHigh5 = 59;
And, in the last lessonâ€™s application, we averaged the 5 values like this:
tempAvg = (tempHigh1 + tempHigh2 + tempHigh3 +
           tempHigh4 + tempHigh5) / 5;

3.1 Grouping values
But, in programming we want to group related values together.Â  So, instead of creating 5 different variables, we create one vector that has 5 values:
tempHigh = c(65, 57, 61, 64, 59);
One of the main reasons to create a vector is that the values in the vector are all associated and we can perform mathematical operations on the whole vector.Â  For instance, the vector might consist of multiple temperatures in Fahrenheit and want to convert all the temperatures to Celsius:
tempHighCel = (5/9) * (tempHigh - 32)
Or, we can use one of Râ€™s many, many statistical functions, mean(), on the vector:
tempMean = mean(tempHigh); 
After executing the code in this section, we can see in the Environment tab that tempHighCel has 5 converted temperatures and that tempMean is the same as tempAvg:
tempAvg:     61.2
tempHigh:    num [1:5] 65 57 61 64 59
tempHighCel: num [1:5] 18.3 139 16.1 17.5 15
tempMean:    61.2






FigureÂ 1: View of temperature values in Environment



Extension: Statistical functions on vectors


3.2 Indexing values in a vector
Putting values into vectors also allows us to associate values between vectors.Â  If we have a vector of high temperature values, then we could also have a vector of low temperature values.
tempLow = c(45, 40, 55, 37, 42);
We can directly subtract tempLow values from tempHigh to get the difference in temperature for all values:
tempDiff = tempHigh - tempLow;
We can index individual values.Â  You could think of the vector as 5 days.Â  And if you want, you can find the change in temperature for any day using the index 1 through 5:
tempDiff_3 = tempHigh[3] - tempLow[3];
tempDiff_5 = tempHigh[5] - tempLow[5];
The Environment shows:
tempHigh:    num [1:5] 65 57 61 64 59
tempLow:     num [1:5] 45 40 55 37 42
tempDiff:    num [1:5] 20 17 6 27 17
tempDiff_3:  6
tempDiff_5:  17


3.3 Vectors and columns in a data frame
Data frames are made up of vectors that all have the same length.Â  The vectors are the columns in the data frame and the number of values in the vector is determined by the number of rows in the data frame.
Â 
In FigureÂ 2 there is a weather data frame (note: we are using this data frame in future lessons, not this one) where each column has a measured daily weather value (e.g., minTemp, maxTemp, relHum).Â  Each row gives the measured weather values for a specific day (e.g., row 1 is Jan 1, row 2 is Jan 2).






FigureÂ 2: A data frame viewed in RStudio with 23 variables (i.e., the 23 columns, which are vector variables)

title: 1-04: Vectors and Data Frames
text:
4 CSV files
In the first couple of lessons we were using data from inside the script but most of the data you will use will come from outside the script â€“ often from a data frame. The data frames themselves often come from a CSV file. CSV stands for Comma Separated Values, meaning that the values in the file are separated by commas.
Â 
Note: CSV is really just a text file that can be read in any text editor and CSV file do not have to use commas as separators.
Â 
Letâ€™s look at a small data set we downloaded in the SectionÂ 1.1 section called twoWeekWeatherData.csv, which contains two weeks of weather data from Lansing, Michigan.Â 

4.1 Opening a CSV file
Note: CSV files are often opened by default in Excel and this can problematic: Trap: Opening CSV files in Excel
Â 
CSV files are just text files and CSV files can be opened in any text editor (e.g., notepad, notepad++, textEdit).
Â 
RStudio is also a text editor so we can open and edit twoWeekWeatherData.csv in RStudio by either:

Clicking File -> Open Fileâ€¦ and navigate to twoWeekWeatherData.csv and press OK.
Using the Files tab: navigate to the data folder, click on twoWeekWeatherData.csv, choose View File (FigureÂ 3)







FigureÂ 3: The twoWeekWeatherData.csv file opened in RStudio



Â 
The CSV file has 15 lines (rows).Â  The first row contains the 5 column headers and the other 14 rows contain the 5 values for each date â€“ all separated by a comma.


4.2 Reading in a CSV file
We can see that the CSV file has a header row and each row has five values representing: date, highTemp, lowTemp, precipitation, noonCondition.
Â 
To use the data in a script we need to read the data into a script file â€“ and for that we will use the read.csv() function.
# Get the data from the twoWeekWeatherData CSV file
weatherData = Â«read.csvÂ»(file="data/twoWeekWeatherData.csv", 
                       sep=",",
                       header=TRUE);
read.csv() reads in the data from the CSV file â€“ and saves the data to a variable called weatherData.
Â 
weatherData is a data frame variable and it appears in the Environment tab under Data as 14 obs. of 5 variables. (i.e., 14 rows and 5 columns), which matches what we saw in the CSV file (FigureÂ 3).Â 

Double-clicking on weatherData opens the data frame in the File Viewer window.Â  This is a convenient way to visualize the data frame.
Clicking on the blue arrow to the left of weatherData provides information about each of the columns







FigureÂ 4: Viewing the data frame in the File Viewer





4.3 Column value type
In the Environment, when you click on the arrow next to the left of weatherData (FigureÂ 2) you see some information about the columns in the data frame. The first piece of information is the name of the column (i.e., the header â€“ date, highTemp, etc.).Â  The second is the type of value the column contains.
Â 
In weatherData there are three types of values:

int (e.g., highTemp and lowTemp): integer â€“ or non-decimal numbers
num (e.g., precipitation): numeric, or numbers with decimals
chr: (e.g, noonCoondition) this stands for character, and character is really short for string of characters, and this in turn is typically shortened to string.Â  Whatever you call it, it is the catch-all category for values R cannot recognize as anything else.Â 

Â 
Note: the date column has date values but it is not formatted properly so R does not recognize it as a Date â€“ something we will cover much later.

title: 1-04: Vectors and Data Frames
text:
5 Functions and arguments
read.csv() is a function that tells R to open a file and treat it like a CSV file. A function is a set of code separate from your main script that performs a common task (e.g., plotting values, finding a standard deviation, reading in a file).
Â 
There is a lot going on in our first line of code and that is because there are a lot of options, called arguments, when opening up a CSV file!Â  We will talk a little bit about these arguments here and save the rest of the discussion for the next lesson.
Â 
Inside the function read.csv(), I included three arguments (file, sep, and header).Â  Arguments are like the knobs and dials for a function.Â  The function reads a CSV file and the arguments tweak how the CSV file is read.

5.1 file
file = â€œdata/twoWeekWeatherData.csvâ€ means that the script opens the file called twoWeekWeatherData.csv located in the data folder of your RStudio Project
Â 
This only works if you are in the RStudio Project because the RStudio Project sets the Working Directory to your Project Folder.
Â 
If you execute the script file outside your RStudio Project (FigureÂ 5), you will get a cannot open file error in the Console because the script does not know to find the CSV file.






FigureÂ 5: You get a cannot open file error if you try to execute the script outside of your RStudio Project





5.2 sep
sep = â€œ,â€ means that the values in the file are separated by commas.Â  This is not always true â€“ even for CSV files.
Â 
The most common alternate separator values are spaces ( sep = â€ â€œ ) and dots ( sep = â€œ.â€ )


5.3 header
header = TRUE means the first row contains header information. In this case the header information is the column names (date, highTemp, lowTemp, and precipitation)
Â 
header = FALSE would mean that the first row contains data (i.e., there are no column names).Â  If you set header=FALSE in this example then R will think that the column names are the first data point.Â  So, you will have 15 values in each vector and the first value will not make sense.


5.4 Default values for arguments
By default, read.csv() assumes sep=â€œ,â€ and header=TRUE. For the data in this example, sep and header are not needed and this code would work:
weatherData = read.csv(file="data/twoWeekWeatherData.csv");
But I like to keep sep and header in my code because you often do need to change them (e.g., you have data without a header or spaces between values instead of commas) and it is easier to deal with if you already have sep and header when copying code from one script to another.

title: 1-04: Vectors and Data Frames
text:
6 Getting data
We now have a data frame with weather information stored in a variable called weatherData.Â  But, we usually do not want to deal with the whole data frame at once.Â  So, our next trick will be to extract parts of the data from the data frame.Â  We might want to work with one column in the data frame (e.g., highTemp or precipitation).Â  We can see all the columns in the data frame by expanding the data frame in the Environment or looking at the headers in the File Viewer (both views are in FigureÂ 4).Â 

6.1 Pulling out a column
Columns in a data frame are vectors (i.e., a variable with multiple values) and we can save the columns to a vector.Â  We can access the columns from a data frame using the $ operator.
Â 
We start with weatherData and, use the dollar sign operator ( $ ) to access the highTemp column, and save the results to the vector called highTemps:
highTemps = weatherData$highTemp;
In the Environment square brackets ([ ] ) indicates the variable is a vector.Â  highTemps appears in the Environment as a vector.Â  highTemps has 14 ( [1:14] ) integer (int) values, representing the temperature for each of the 14 days.Â 






FigureÂ 6: The highTemps vector variable in the Environment tab





6.2 Pulling out (subsetting) individual values
Perhaps we want just one value â€“ specifically, we want to know the high temperature on April 2 (the seventh day in weatherData).
Â 
There are multiple ways to access that individual value.Â  I will present three, but for the rest of this lesson, we are going to use the first method.
Â 
We could subset using the subset operator ( [ ] ) the 7th value from highTemps:
highTempDay7a = highTemps[7];
We could go back to the original data frame (weatherData) and subset the 7th value from the column highTemp:
highTempDay7b = weatherData$highTemp[7];
Or, we can use a row/column (e.g., X/Y) operation on weatherData to get the value:
highTempDay7c = weatherData[7, "highTemp"];  # think of this as [X,Y] notation
The last method is functionally the same as the previous two â€“ but the X,Y notation is the most robust as it can best handle more complex subsetting situations (e.g., subsetting multiple rows and columns), which will be discussed in a future lesson.


6.3 The Environment and the L value
I will be referring quite often to the Environment tab as it looks after the script has been sourced (as in FigureÂ 6) .Â  Instead of taking a screenshot of the Environment tab (which is hard to maintain), I will display the variables I am focused on like this:
highTemp7a:  60L
highTemp7b:  60L
highTemp7c:  60L
The Environment tab shows that highTemp7a, highTemp7b, and highTemp7c are all equal to 60L
Â 
The L indicates that the number is explicitly an integer, not just a numeric values that happens to have all zeros in its decimal.

title: 1-04: Vectors and Data Frames
text:
7 Pulling out multiple values
We have pulled out a column from a data frame and we have pulled out individual values.Â  In this section, we will show different ways to pull out multiple values with:

An index vector created using c()
A regular (or, simple) sequence using the colon ( : ) operator
A more complex sequence using the seq() function


7.1 Using a numeric vector to pull multiple values
highTemps is a vector with 14 values and each of these values can be accessed by their numeric placement:
val_01 = highTemps[1];
val_05 = highTemps[5];
val_12 = highTemps[12];
Or, we might want to combine the temperatures from these three days into one variable.Â  c() creates a vector of the three values (1, 5, and 12) and that vector is used to subset highTemps:
valComb = highTemps[c(1,5,12)];  # a vector with 3 values
valComb is a vector with 3 values, the high temperature for days 1, 5, and 12:



val_01:    57L
val_05:    39L
val_12:    54L
valComb:   int [1:3] 57 39 54


FigureÂ 7: The three values we pulled from highTemps individually saved and combined (valComb)





7.2 Pulling out consecutive values
If we want to get the high temperature for consecutive days, we can use the simple sequencing ( : ) operator â€“ simple refers to the fact that we are sequencing by 1:
consecVals = highTemps[3:11];  # same as highTemps[c(3,4,5,6,7,8,9,10,11)]
consecVals is a vector with 9 values â€“ the high temperatures from days 3 through 11.Â  Note: 9 values, not 8 â€“ we include both the 3 and the 11.
Â 
The ( : ) operator also works in reverse
consecValsRev = highTemps[11:3];
consecValsRev is a vector with 9 values â€“ the high temperatures from days 11 down to 3.



consecVals:     int [1:9] 54 40 39 ...
consecValsRev:  int [1:9] 39 44 55 ...


FigureÂ 8: int [1:9] means 9 values are in each vector â€“ the first few values are shown





7.3 Using the Console to view values in a vector
The Environment tab is good for quickly looking at values, but it only shows a few values from each vector.Â  If you want to see all the values then you can use the Console tab (bottom-left corner).Â  In the Console tab, type in the variable you want to see and press Enter:






FigureÂ 9: Using the Console tab to view variables



Â 
These two values, consecVals and consecValRev, are shown in the Console window in FigureÂ 9. In the future I will present the Console like this:
> consecVals 
[1] 54 40 39 58 60 53 55 44 39 
> consecValsRev 
[1] 39 44 55 53 60 58 39 40 54


7.4 Using a sequence to get values
We can use the seq() to create a more complex sequence to subset a vector.
Â 
This is a two step process:

Create a sequence.Â 
Use the sequence to subset the vector.Â 


7.4.1 Creating a sequence
seq() is a function with three arguments:

from: the starting point
to: the ending point
by: the iteration

Â 
We can create a sequence that lists every other number from 1-14
seq1 = seq(from=1, to=14, by=2);
We can reverse the sequence by switching the to and from and inverting the by
seq2 = seq(from=14, to=1, by=-2);
We can get every 3rd number for the first 10 numbers:
seq3 = seq(from=1, to=10, by=3);
The 3 sequences we created are just vectors of numbers:
seq1:   1 3 5 7 9 11 13
seq2:   14 12 10 8 6 4 2
seq3:   1 4 7 10


7.4.2 Using the sequences as indexes
We can use the 3 sequences above as index vectors to index the highTemps vector:
Â 
Get every other high temperature:
highTempSeq1 = highTemps[seq1];
Get every other high temperature in reverse:
highTempSeq2 = highTemps[seq2];
Get every 3rd high temperature value in the first 10 values:
highTempSeq3 = highTemps[seq3];



highTempSeq1:  int [1:7] 57 54 39 60 ...
highTempSeq2:  int [1:7] 75 54 44 53 ...
highTempSeq3:  int [1:4] 57 40 60 44


FigureÂ 10: There are 7 values in the first two sequences and 4 in the third





7.4.3 Combining the above 2 steps
You can combine the above two steps in 1 command.
Â 
The following command will give you the same high temperature values:
highTempSeq1b = highTemps[seq(from=1, to=14, by=2)];  
highTempSeq2b = highTemps[seq(from=14, to=1, by=-2)];  
highTempSeq3b = highTemps[seq(from=1, to=10, by=3)];
Extension: Square brackets [ ] vs.Â Round Brackets ( )


7.4.4 Note about combining steps in R
While it might seem like combining steps is a good idea because it reduces the amount of code, this needs to be balanced with the fact that combining code usually makes it harder to read.Â  One of the big problems I see when looking at peopleâ€™s code is that they cram too much code into one command and it becomes really difficult to debug if anything goes wrong.Â  If you are going to err on one side then this author recommends you err on the side of breaking up code rather than combining it.

section: 9 Trap: Opening CSV files in Excel
text:
9 Trap: Opening CSV files in Excel
If you have Excel on your computer, then it is probable that Excel is the default program for opening CSV files.Â  This means double-clicking on a CSV file will open it in Excel.Â  The danger with opening CSV files in Excel is that Excel will sometimes reformat the data (especially date and money columns) and then give a message saying how the data needs to be saved to be preserved.Â  Do not save the file â€“ it will change the format of your data.Â  If you are editing a CSV file in Excel then I would save the results to a test file first to make sure Excel did not do anything untoward.






FigureÂ 12: Opening a CSV file in Excel â€“ the possible data loss warning is not something you want to heed

title: 1-04: Vectors and Data Frames
text:
10 Extension: Long and Short Integers
L stands for Long integer â€“ long meaning that this variable can hold a number larger than 256.Â  In the old days, when space on computers was VERY expensive, programmers would save space by having a short integer and long integer designation.Â  So, if a programmer knew a number was small, they would assign it to a short integer to take up less space on the computer.Â  Since temperatures in Lansing are generally going to be less than 256 (unless you are using the Kelvin system), it is safe to assign temperatures to short integers.
Â 
Nowadays, space is so cheap that we rarely care that we are using a tiny bit more memory than we need â€“ so L has become mostly a relic of the past.

title: 1-04: Vectors and Data Frames
1-04: Vectors and Data Frames
section: 12 Extension: Square brackets [ ] vs.Â Round Brackets ( )
text:
12 Extension: Square brackets [ ] vs.Â Round Brackets ( )
Square brackets are used when you are subsetting or indexing a variable.
Round brackets are used when you are calling a function and contain the arguments for that function.
â€¦ and the two types of brackets are often used in the same command
lowTemps [seq(from=12, to=2, by=-2)]
says you are going to subset lowTemps using the function seq().Â 
> lowTemps [seq(from=12, to=2, by=-2)]
[1] 43 40 50 45 38 43
seq() is a function and produces a vector of numbers:
> seq(from=12, to=2, by=-2)
[1] 12 10 8 6 4 2
c() is also a function â€“ c stands, unintuitively, for concatenate and will also produce a vector of numbers:
> c(12,10,8,6,4,2)
[1] 12 10 8 6 4 2
lowTemps [c(12,10,8,6,4,2)] and lowTemps [seq(from=12, to=2, by=-2)] produce the same results.
Â 
You can also subset lowTemps without calling a function:
> lowTemps[5]
[1] 36
> lowTemps[4:8]
[1] 38 36 45 32 50
Technically, 4:8 still calls the sequence seq(from=4, to=8, by=1) in the background â€“ but that is really getting into the weeds!
Â 
read.csv(), ggplot(), plot(), rm() are all functions.Â  There will be a lot more about functions in this class starting with next lesson.

title: 1-06: Run and Source
text:
2 Output to console
In the next couple of lesson we are going to make extensive use of the Console tab, which can be used to execute code and as output for your script file.Â  Like the Environment tab, it is difficult to maintain images so I will use text instead.
Â 
For example:

open the script for this lesson in your RStudio Project
click on line 4 (i.e., put the cursor on line 4)
click Run

Â 
The RStudio window looks like this:






FigureÂ 1: Output to the Console tab after executing line 6



Â 
Instead of displying the RStudio image, I will display the output to the Console tab like this:



Â«>Â»   ### Output a text message
Â«>Â»   cat("Hello"); 
Hello


FigureÂ 2: Output to the Console tab after executing line 4

title: 1-06: Run and Source
text:
3 Run vs.Â Source
The Source button is used to execute the whole script (i.e., every command in the script) while the Run button is used to selectively execute commands.Â  Run is a great tool for debugging and testing your code and we are going to almost exclusively use Run for the next two lessons.
Â 
The next two lessons are more about showing off features in R and RStudio and not about creating a full script.Â  However, your goal with most scripts is to be able to execute the file using Source.Â  It takes longer to develop you script using Source but it forces you to automate your script which makes your script both easier to debug and share.

3.1 Executing one line
We already have an example of using Run to execute one line in FigureÂ 2.Â  When we put the cursor on line 4 and clicked Run, R executed the cat() command on line 4.Â  We will talk much more about cat() next lesson but cat() outputs to the Console whatever is in the parentheses.
Â 
Actually, clicking Run does not just execute the line, but everything associate with the command on the line.Â  When you look at the Console output, you see that lines 3 and 4 were both executed â€“ but line 3 was just a comment line so it does not do anything.



>   ### Output a text message  
>   cat("Hello");             
Hello                          


FigureÂ 3: Lines in Console that start with a ( > ) are command lines





3.2 Executing multiple commands on one line
You can put as many command as you want on one line as long as use semicolons between them.
Â 
The following line has three commands that

create two variables (a and b)
output the addition of them to the Console.Â 

a=3; b=7; cat("a+b=", a+b);
Clicking Run on the line will add a and b to the Environment:
a:   3
b:   7
And the addition of a and b is displayed in the Console:
>   ### Multiple commands on one line
>   a=3; b=7; cat("a+b=", a+b);
a+b= 10
If you remove the semicolons then you will get the error: unexpected symbol in â€ Â a=3 bâ€
Basically, R is saying the it does not understand what the symbol b means because R thinks that b is a continuation of the a=3 command.


3.3 Executing highlighted script
You can also highlight parts of your script and Run will executed exactly what is highlighted.
Â 
If you completely highlight lines 10, 11, and 12:
  cat("Hello, World.\n");
  cat("How are you?\n");
  cat("I am fine?\n");
and click Run, the output to the Console is:



>   cat("Hello, World.\n");
Hello, World.
>   cat("How are you?\n");
How are you?
>   cat("I am fine?\n");
I am fine?


FigureÂ 4: Three commands sent to Console by clicking Run



When you highlight code and click Run, Run will execute exactly what you highlight.Â  So, if you accidentally highlight a bit of line 9 along with lines 10-12:
  ### Outputting multiple text messages Â«(\n means go to next line)Â»
  Â«cat("Hello, World.\n");Â»
  Â«cat("How are you?\n");Â»
  Â«cat("I am fine?\n");Â»
Then in the Console you will get the error:
> (\n means go to next line)
Error: unexpected symbol in "(\n"
R is trying to execute the last part of line 9 and R does not know that this is supposed to be part of a comment because you did not highlight the ### part of the line.
Â 
To recap, when you click Run andâ€¦:

â€¦the cursor is in a line: R will execute all commands on that line.
â€¦part of your code is highlighted: R will execute exactly what is highlighted



3.4 Executing one command on multiple lines
Lines 15-17 contain the command to open the twoWeekWeatherData.csv file and save the data to a data frame named weatherData.
  ### read in data from  twoWeekWeatherData.csv
  weatherData = read.csv(file="data/twoWeekWeatherData.csv", 
                         sep=",",
                         header=TRUE);
If we put the cursor on any line from 15-17 and click Run, R will execute all 3 lines.Â  When you click Run, R will execute whatever command the cursor is in the middle of.Â  In this case, the command starts on line 15 with weatherData = and ends on line 17 with header=TRUE);.
Â 
When we Run line 15, the Console output shows lines 14-17 (14 is a comment) were executed â€“ the ( + ) at the beginning of the lines in the Console says that this line is a continuation of the command from the previous line.



>   ### read in data from  twoWeekWeatherData.csv
>   weatherData = read.csv(file="data/twoWeekWeatherData.csv", 
Â«+Â»                         sep=",",
Â«+Â»                          header=TRUE);


FigureÂ 5: Console output when executing the multi-line command to open the csv file



Executing lines 14-17 means that you have a new variable named weatherData and this variable is put in the Environment tab:



weatherData   14 obs. of 5 variables


FigureÂ 6: The Environment tab after the read.csv() command was executed

title: 1-06: Run and Source
text:
4 Entering commands directly into Console
When you click Run you are sending commands to the Console, but you can directly type commands in the Console â€“ and it will produce the same results.
Â 
So, if you type cat(â€œHelloâ€) into the Console you will get:
> cat("Hello")
Hello
A common issue for people using the Console is that they will not complete commands.Â  For example, type cat(â€œHe in the Console and press enter:
> cat("He
+

3 Four structures in programming
As mentioned in the second lesson on variables,Â there are basically 4 main structures that cover almost every aspect of programming:

Variables
If-Else Statements
For Loops
Functions

Â 
In the next two lessons we cover If-Else statements

title: 1-08: Conditional Operations
text:
4 Non-linear scripts
So far all of our scripts have been linear â€“ in other words, the execution of the script goes line-by-line, or command-by-command, until the end of the script.Â  However, most scripts do not work like this â€“ most scripts have multiple points where the execution of code is:

moved to another location (i.e., functions â€“ future lesson)
done multiple times (i.e., for loops â€“ future lesson)
dependent on some condition (i.e., if-else statements â€“ this lesson)

Â 
And you will often find combinations of the above.Â  When dealing with data frames, if-else statements are often found within for loops.Â  For example, a for loop goes through every value in a temperature column and an embedded if-else statement executes code if the temperature is above a certain amount.
Â 
For the next couple of lessons we are just going to focus on if-else statements.Â  After that, we will introduce for loops with embedded if-else statements.

title: 1-08: Conditional Operations
text:
5 Questions and Statements
The if() statement can almost be thought of as a question with a yes/no answer:

Is the fishâ€™s weight below 100 grams?Â  (yes/no)
Is the first runnerâ€™s speed greater than the second runnerâ€™s speed? (yes/no)
Is the location Silver Lake? (yes/no)
Is the temperature less than or equal to 30?Â (yes/no)

Â 
Except, instead of questions with yes/no answer, if() contains statements with TRUE/FALSE conditions:

The fishâ€™s weight is below 100 grams. (TRUE/FALSE)
The first runnerâ€™s speed is greater than the second runnerâ€™s speed. (TRUE/FALSE)
The location is Silver Lake. (TRUE/FALSE)
The temperature is less than or equal to 30. (TRUE/FALSE)


5.1 Structure of an if() statement
The basic structure of an if() statement is:



if (some conditional statement is TRUE)
{ 
   # Execute the code in this codeblock
   # if the conditional statement is TRUE.
   # note: All command within the codeblock are indented
}
# next lesson we will cover what happens if the conditional statement is FALSE.


FigureÂ 1: Structure of an if() statement



Inside the curly brackets ( {Â  } ) attached to the if() is a codeblock, or a series of commands, that gets executed if the statement is TRUE.Â  If the statement is FALSE, the codeblock is skipped.
Â 
Letâ€™s do a simple example where a random number is picked and an if() statement checks the random number:



randomTemp = sample(30:80, size=1);  # pick a random number between 30 and 80

if (randomTemp > 50)  # if randomTemp is greater than 50...
{ 
  # ...execute the commands in this codeblock
  cat("The temperature is", randomTemp);
  cat("warm enough to go outside\n");
}
# next lesson we will cover what happens if the conditional statement is FALSE.


FigureÂ 2: An example of an if() statement





5.2 Alternate codeblock format
The curly brackets ( {Â  } ) designate the beginning and the end of the codeblock.Â  There are many ways to space the curly brackets but only two methods that are generally accepted in the programming world:

FigureÂ 2 where the curly brackets are on their own line and lined up at the same level as the if() and all code inside is indented
FigureÂ 3 where the start bracket is on the same line as the if() statement â€“ everything else is the same as the first example




if (randomTemp > 50)  { # if randomTemp is greater than 50...
  # ...execute the commands in this codeblock
  cat("The temperature is", randomTemp);
  cat("warm enough to go outside\n");
}
# next lesson we will cover what happens if the conditional statement is FALSE.


FigureÂ 3: Alternate structure of an if() statement



I prefer the first method because it makes it easier for me to visualize the hierarchy of the codeblocks and easier to comment. You are required to use one of these two methods in this class.
Â 
Extension: Curly bracket placement

title: 1-08: Conditional Operations
text:
6 If() statements
The conditional statement inside the parentheses of the if() contains at least two values being compared with a conditional operation:
if( fishWeight Â«<Â» 100 )                # is greater than
if( runner1Speed Â«>Â» runner2Speed)      # is less than
if( location Â«==Â» "Silver Lake" )       # is equal to
if( temperature Â«<=Â» 30 )               # is less than or equal to
A conditional operator does two things:
1) It compares the two values on both sides of the operator.Â 
2) It outputs either TRUE or FALSE based on results of the comparison.
Note: TRUE/ FALSE statements are often called Boolean statements

6.1 Conditional Operators in R
There are six conditional operators in programming:







Operator
Meaning




==
equal to
(easily confused with the assignment operator, =)


!=
not equal to
(reverses the logic of ==)


>=
greater than or equal to


<=
less than or equal to


>
greater then (only)


<
less than (only)



Note: >=, <=, >, and < operators are usually used to compare two numeric values. However they can be used to compare string values.
Extension: Greater than and less than on strings


6.2 Set up conditional operators
The following if statements all compare two values using a conditional operator:
if( fishWeight Â«<Â» 100 )
{
  # code that gets executed if fishWeight < 100
}
if( runner1Speed Â«>Â» runner2Speed )
{
  # code that gets executed if runner1Speed > runner2Speed
}
if( location Â«==Â» "Silver Lake" )
{
  # code that gets executed if location == "Silver Lake"
}
if( temperature Â«<=Â» 30)
{
  # code that gets executed if temperature <= 30
}
Note: A single Conditional Operators compares two values (e.g., location == â€œSilver Lakeâ€).Â  In a future lesson, we will learn how to deal with more complex conditions (e.g., how to check if location is â€œSilver Lakeâ€ or â€œRound Lakeâ€).

section: 14 Extension: Greater than and less than on strings
text:
14 Extension: Greater than and less than on strings
Greater than and less than conditional operator do work on strings.Â  If the strings only have letters from the English alphabet, then > and < will do an alphabetical comparison between the values.Â  In this case, > means â€œlater in the alphabetâ€.Â  So, â€œCâ€ > â€œBâ€, â€œDâ€ > â€œCâ€â€¦
> "Frank" > "Charlie"
[1] TRUE
> "Bob" > "Charlie"
[1] FALSE
> "Bob" > "Barb"
[1] TRUE
If you use characters that are not in the English alphabet then R will look at the Unicode character code.Â  Unicode character codes are unique numbers assigned to every imaginable character.Â  The English letters start at 65 in the Unicode chart.Â  The main use for Unicode character codes is that they allow someone to use and output characters that are not on your keyboard like the Î¶ , which is character number 950.Â 
Even though > and < works on all characters, it has limited usefulness.

title: 1-08: Conditional Operations
text:
15 Extension: Numbers as Characters
A common problem in R is that variables that look like numbers can really be a string/character.
Â 
If you add these variables to your script:
num1 = 50;
num2 = "50";
Then num1 is an integer but num2 is a string/character.
In other words, num1 is 50 and num2 is the character â€œ5â€ followed by the character â€œ0â€.
Â 
This means the mathematical and conditional operators will not work on num2 as you would expect:



> num2 > 30
[1] TRUE
> num2 > 70
[1] FALSE
> num2 > 300
[1] TRUE
> num2 > 7
[1] FALSE


FigureÂ 4: Conditional operators on numbers that are really string/characters: num2 = â€œ50â€



Since num2 is â€œ50â€, the first two seem correct, â€œ50â€ is greater than 30 and not greater than 70.
Â 
But adding or taking away â€œ0â€ does not change the result of the conditional operator so â€œ50â€ is still greater than 300 and not greater than 7.
Â 
This happens because R does not think of â€œ50â€ as a number but as two characters, a â€œ5â€ and a â€œ0â€.Â  And since R sees â€œ50â€ as two character, R is making an alphabetical comparison of the â€œnumbersâ€:



> num2 > "30"
[1] TRUE
> num2 > "70"
[1] FALSE
> num2 > "300"
[1] TRUE
> num2 > "7"
[1] FALSE


FigureÂ 5: Conditional operators on strings that have numbers in them



Alphabetic comparisons start with the leftmost character so â€œFrankâ€ is greater than â€œCharlieâ€ and not greater than â€œHarryâ€. Using this logic, R sees â€œ5â€ as greater than â€œ3â€ and not greater than â€œ7â€.Â  It does not matter what, or how many, â€œnumbersâ€ come afterwards
Â 
When doing an alphabetical comparison, if the first character is different then you do not need to look beyond the first character when doing a conditional operator.
