title: 2-07: Matrices
text:
2 Script for the lesson
The script for the lesson is here
The LansingJanTemps.csv

title: 2-07: Matrices
text:
3 CSV files
Letâ€™s first look at the CSV file, LansingJanTemps.csv.Â  The data in the CSV file was downloaded from the NOAA/NCDC website and contains the high temperature for every day in January from 2011 to 2016.
Â 
A CSV file is a text file that can be read by any text editor.Â  We can look at the csv file by clicking on it in the Files tab of RStudio and choosing View File.Â  The file will open in RStudioâ€™s file viewer:






FigureÂ 1: Opening and viewing a CSV file in RStudio



The temperature values are in tenths of a Celsius degree and the columns have generic names â€“ we will deal with both of these issues later.

3.1 Saving data to a data frame
Letâ€™s open the CSV file and save it to a data frame, named lansingJanDF:
lansingJanDF = read.csv(file = "data/LansingJanTemps.csv");
lansingJanDF is a data frame with 6 columns of January temperatures from the years 2011-2016.Â  This view of lansingJanDF is just a more structured view of the data from FigureÂ 1.






FigureÂ 2: Viewing the data frame from the CSV file





3.2 Column name change
Letâ€™s create a copy of the data frame so we can maintain the original data frame while making changes:
lansingJanDF2 = lansingJanDF;
We want to change the column names to something that has the years in it.Â We can change the name of all six columns at once to the six years 2011-2016 using the sequence 2011:2016:
colnames(lansingJanMat2) = 2011:2016;
But, it is not recommended to start a column name with a number.Â  Column names are essentially variable names and variable names cannot start with a number.Â  R does allow you to start a column name with a number, but there are problems with this that are beyond the scope of this lesson.
Â 
To avoid problems, you should always use variable naming standards for column names in a dataframe even though R does not enforce this.
Â 
As a reminder, the are that variable names :

can only start with a letter, underscore ( _ ) , or a dot ( . )

remember: most programming language do not accept dots ( . ) in names

can consist of letters, numbers, underscore ( _ ), or a dot ( . )
cannot have spaces
cannot be reserved words (e.g., if, else, TRUE, FALSE, function, for)
Â 

We are going to name the columns Jan2011, Jan2012â€¦ using paste() to create the six column names:
colnames(lansingJanMat2) = paste("Jan", 2011:2016, sep="");
Note: we needed to set sep=â€œâ€œ, otherwise there would be a space in the name






FigureÂ 3: Changing the column names â€“ make sure column names follow the same rules as variable names

title: 2-07: Matrices
text:
4 Data frames and matrices (two-dimensional data)
A data frame is a two dimensional data structure that is a collection of related vectors (i.e., columns). For instance, the weatherData data frame used in previous lessons had different types of weather data (columns) collected every day (rows).
Â 
Data frames, by design, have columns that hold different types of data.Â  The weather data from previous lessons had temperature columns, humidity columns, precipitation columns, etc..
Â 
However, in this lesson, we have a data frame where all the columns are the same type of value (temperatures) and we will want to perform calculations across rows, columns, and the whole structure.Â  This cannot be done with a data frame, but it can be done with a matrix.
Â 
A matrix is a two-dimensional vector that is similar to a two-dimensional data frame except that all the columns are the same type of value.
Â 
We can convert a data frame directly into a matrix using as.matrix():
lansingJanMat = as.matrix(lansingJanDF2);
In the Environment tab, the matrix is placed in the Data section (like a data frame), but is presented as a two-dimensional vector (31 rows by 6 columns):
lansingJanMat: num [1:31, 1:6] 122 -39 6 0 -50 -33 ...
And, if you double-click on the matrix, it will show up in a Viewer tab and look like a data frame:






FigureÂ 4: Matrices and data frame in the Environment â€“ double-clicking on a matrix opens it in a Viewer tab




4.1 Advantages of a matrix
A matrix has two advantages over a data frame:

a matrix allows you to perform calculations across rows and the whole structure
operations are faster on a matrix than on a data frame
Â 

If you are dealing with large data that is all of the same type, then it is best to use a matrix.

title: 2-07: Matrices
text:
5 Modifying the whole matrix
The temperature data in the lansingJanMat is in units of tenths of Celsius (this author does not know why NOAA/NCDC chose to store the data this way).Â  Letâ€™s convert this to Fahrenheit.
Â 
Because this is a matrix, we can execute mathematical operations on all values at once â€“ just like a vector (remember, a matrix is a two-dimensional vector).
Â 
In order, we will:

change the units from tenth of a Celsius to CelsiusÂ 
convert the temperatures from Celsius to Fahrenheit
change values to two significant digits


5.1 Calculations on the whole matrix
We are going to perform three operations on the matrix and show the results of the operations on the first 10 values of the matrix.
Â 
Note: I create a new matrices to maintain the old versions of the matrix, but this is not necessary â€“ you could keep saving the results to lansingJanMat.Â 
Â 
The first 10 values in the matrix are:
> lansingJanMat[1:10]
 [1] 122 -39   6   0 -50 -33 -72 -56 -28 -39
# Step 1) Divide by 10 to get units from tenths of Celsius to Celsius
lansingJanMat2 = lansingJanMat / 10;
> lansingJanMat2[1:10]
 [1] 12.2 -3.9  0.6  0.0 -5.0 -3.3 -7.2 -5.6 -2.8 -3.9
# Step 2)  Converting from Celsius to Fahrenheit
lansingJanMat3 = (9/5) * lansingJanMat2 + 32;
> lansingJanMat3[1:10]
 [1] 53.96 24.98 33.08 32.00 23.00 26.06 19.04 21.92 26.96 24.98
# Step 3) Set the number of significant digits to 2
lansingJanMat4 = signif(x=lansingJanMat3, digits=2);



> lansingJanMat4[1:10]
 [1] 54 25 33 32 23 26 19 22 27 25


FigureÂ 5: Displaying the first ten temperature values of the 4 matrices









FigureÂ 6: The final matrix in the Viewer tab





5.2 Statistical operation on the whole matrix
We can also apply statistical functions to the whole matrix.Â  For instance, we can find the mean and standard deviation of all values in the matrix:
meanAllTemps = mean(lansWeatherMat4);
sdAllTemps = sd(lansingJanMat4);
> meanAllTemps
[1] 29.68495
> sdAllTemps
[1] 10.60749

title: 2-07: Matrices
text:
6 Subsetting matricesÂ 
If we just want to work with part of the data in a matrix, then we need to subset the matrix.Â  Similar to the bracket notation, [x], for one-dimensional vectors, we can use two-dimensional bracket [x,y] notation to subset a matrix.
Â 
In this notation, x represents the row numbers to subset and y represents the column numbers to subset.

6.1 Subset a column in a matrix
If x is not given, it means take all rows (i.e., do not subset the rows).Â  So, the following will find the mean of all rows in column 3 (i.e., all values in the year 2013):
meanJan2013 = mean(lansWeatherMat[ ,3]);



> lansingJanMat4[,3]
 [1] 25 26 29 33 35 35 35 38 45 44 55 58 40 26 29 34 33 35 45 41
[21] 15 10 17 16 20 27 30 43 57 56 27
> meanJan2013
[1] 34.16129


FigureÂ 7: Console output for the matrix subsetted by row 3 and the mean of this subset





6.2 Subset a row in a matrix
If y is not given, it means take all columns (i.e., do not subset the columns).Â  So, the following will find the mean of all columns in row 17 (i.e., the Jan 17th value for every year):
meanJan17 = mean(lansWeatherMat[17,]);



> lansingJanMat4[17,]
Jan2011 Jan2012 Jan2013 Jan2014 Jan2015 Jan2016 
     30      40      33      30      45      26 
> meanJan17
[1] 34


FigureÂ 8: Console output for the matrix subsetted by column 17 and the mean of this subset





6.3 Subset both rows and columns in a matrix
And you can use sequences for both x and y to get a two-dimensional subset of the matrix.Â  The following will get the mean of the 10th through 19th (Jan 10-19) values of the first three years (2011, 2012, 2013):
meanJanPart = mean(lansingJanMat4[10:19, 1:3]);



> lansingJanMat4[10:19, 1:3]
      Jan2011 Jan2012 Jan2013
 [1,]      25      47      44
 [2,]      26      50      55
 [3,]      27      37      58
 [4,]      25      26      40
 [5,]      23      22      26
 [6,]      26      24      29
 [7,]      18      42      34
 [8,]      30      40      33
 [9,]      34      24      35
[10,]      22      27      45
> meanJanPart
[1] 33.13333


FigureÂ 9: Console output for the matrix subsetted by rows 10-19 and columns 1-3, and the mean of this subset





6.4 Non-continuous subsetting of rows and column
Finally, you can create more complicated sequences to subset the matrix.Â  The following will find the mean of all even days on odd years.
Â 
Since the subsetting is getting complex, it is best to first create variables that hold the subset values:
  evenDays = seq(from=2, to=31, by=2);
  oddYears = c(1,3,5);  
and then use the variables in the bracket notation:
meanJanEvenOdd = mean(lansingJanMat4[evenDays, oddYears]);



> lansingJanMat4[evenDays, oddYears]
      Jan2011 Jan2013 Jan2015
 [1,]      25      26      34
 [2,]      32      33      32
 [3,]      26      35      17
 [4,]      22      38      13
 [5,]      25      44      16
 [6,]      27      58      27
 [7,]      23      26      19
 [8,]      18      34      32
 [9,]      34      35      39
[10,]      23      41      31
[11,]      16      10      30
[12,]      29      16      37
[13,]      29      27      26
[14,]      29      43      31
[15,]      24      56      23
> meanJanEvenOdd
[1] 29.13333


FigureÂ 10: Console output for the matrix subsetted by even rows and odd columns 1-3, and the mean of this subset

title: 2-07: Matrices
text:
7 Reversing the matrix (transpose)
In the previous examples, the rows represent days and the columns represent years.Â  We could easily reverse the matrix so that the rows represent the years and the columns represent the days. We do this using the transpose, t(), function:
lansingJanMat_T = t(lansingJanMat4);
The resulting matrix has 6 row and 31 columns with temperature values for the months going horizontally across the matrix instead of vertically down:






FigureÂ 11: The transpose matrix (reversing the rows and columns)

title: 2-07: Matrices
section: 8 Statistics across all rows and columns
text:
8 Statistics across all rows and columns
Earlier, we found the mean of a single column of temperature values (FigureÂ 9).Â  Often, we want to find the mean of every column.Â  We could just repeat the same line 6 times, once for each column:
meanJan2011 = mean(lansWeatherMat[ ,1]);
meanJan2012 = mean(lansWeatherMat[ ,2]);
...
But, this is not an efficient way to code and would become more burdensome as the number of columns increases.
Â 
There are two better ways to cycle through each column and get the means:

Use for loops
Use apply()


8.1 For loops
A for loop can be used to cycle through, and calculate the mean of, each column in the matrix.Â  Since there are multiple mean values that you are calculating, you need to save the mean values to one vector.
Â 
The vector needs to be created before the for loop and assigned values during the for loop.Â  After, the for loop the vector will have the same number of values as the matrix has columns (i.e., 6).
# vector that holds the 6 yearly mean values
yearlyMean = c();

# cycle through the six column and find the mean of the temperature values
for(i in 1:6) 
{
  # get the mean of all values in column i and save it to yearlyMean[i]
  yearlyMean[i] = mean(lansingJanMat4[,i]);
}
The yearlyMean vector has 6 values, representing the mean for each of the 6 years:
> yearlyMean
[1] 25.61290 35.77419 34.16129 23.36774 27.45161 31.74194


8.2 apply()
apply() is a useful, if somewhat archaic, function in base R that allows you to apply a statistical or mathematical function for every row or column in a matrix.
Â 
apply() takes three arguments:

the matrix you want to perform the function on
MARGIN: a number indicating whether you want to perform the action on rows or columns

1 means all rows, 2 means all columns

FUN: the function to apply

Â 
So, to get the mean of all columns in the lansingJanMat4 matrix:
  yearlyMean2 = apply(lansingJanMat4, MARGIN=2, FUN=mean);
And, yearlyMean2 is a vector with 6 value, the same as yearlyMean above.
> yearlyMean2
 Jan2011  Jan2012  Jan2013  Jan2014  Jan2015  Jan2016 
25.61290 35.77419 34.16129 23.36774 27.45161 31.74194 
yearlyMean2 is formatted differently than yearlyMean â€“ yearlyMean2 is a named variable.Â  The distinction is something we will look more into in the lesson on Objects in R.

title: 2-07: Matrices
text:
9 Saving the matrix
We are going to save lansingJanMat4 to a CSV files so we can use it in the next lesson and avoid the hassle of reformatting the original CSV file:
write.csv(x=lansWeatherMat, file = "data/LansingJanTempsFixed.csv",    
          row.names = FALSE);
This will put a CSV file named LansingJanTempsFixed.csv in the data folder of your Project Folder.

title: 2-07: Matrices
text:
11 Extension: dataframes and tibbles
In March 2019, the line of code to get a column of temperature values from the lansWeather11Data dataframe (and the other 5 years) changed from
lansWeather11Val = lansWeather11Data [, "value"];
to
lansWeather11Val = lansWeather11Data$value;
The reason for this change is that the NOAA/NCDC database starting sending data in tibbles instead of dataframes.Â  Tibbles are designed to be a more modern take on the dataframe, basically taking the lessons from decades on dataframe usage to create a better dataframe.
Â 
Tibbles are essentially the tidyverse version of a data frame and they supposedly improve on the data frame.
Â 
But, one difference is that in a data frame the three following lines all function exactly the same â€“ they each take the column value from the data frame lw11Data and save it to a vector called temps:
temps=lw11Data$value
temps=lw11Data[, "value"]
temps=lw11Data[["value"]]
However, in a tibble, the following line saves the column value into a new 1 column tibble called temps.
temps=lw11Data[,"value"]
In other words, temps is not a vector, hence the error.
Â 
These two lines work the same in tibbles and data frames:
temps=lw11Data$value
temps=lw11Data[[â€œvalueâ€]]

title: 2-09: Stacking and Mapping
text:
3 GGPlot mapping
This lesson is designed to give an overview of the many issues that occur when you are creating plots in GGPlot and some of the fixes. There is the huge topic of mapping in GGPlot that we use in this lesson, but do not have time to fully explain (we go into much more detail in our dedicated GGPlot classâ€¦).Â  Mapping is how you relate data in a data frame to a visual aspect of a plot.Â  We have already mapped data in a data frame to the x and y axis of a plot â€“ but, you can map many other visual aspects to data like size, shape, and, in this lesson, color.

title: 2-09: Stacking and Mapping
2-09: Stacking and Mapping
text:
5 Line Plots
We are going to go over the multiple ways in GGPlot to make a line plot for each of the 6 temperature column in one canvas area.Â  The ggplot component that creates a line plot is geom_line().
Â 
The simplest way to do it is to create six geom_line() components â€“ one for each column in the data frame:
plot1 = ggplot( data=(lansJanTempsDF), 
                Â«mapping = aes(x=1:31)Â») + 
  geom_line( mapping=aes(y=Jan2011),
             color = "red") +
  geom_line( mapping=aes(y=Jan2012),
             color = "green") +
  geom_line( mapping=aes(y=Jan2013),
             color = "orange") +
  geom_line( mapping=aes(y=Jan2014),
             color = "blue") +
  geom_line( mapping=aes(y=Jan2015),
             color = "purple") +
  geom_line( mapping=aes(y=Jan2016),
             color = "black") +
  labs( title="January Temperature",
        subtitle="Lansing, MI -- 2011-2016",
        x = "January Days",
        y = "temperature (F)") +
  theme_bw();
plot(plot1);
Since the x-axis gets mapped to the same date values (1 to 31) for each line plot, we can place the x mapping in ggplot() call.Â  This makes the x mapping of 1:31 universal for all components in the canvas area.
Â 
Each geom_line component is also customized with a color subcomponent.






FigureÂ 1: A line plot for the six temperature columns

title: 2-09: Stacking and Mapping
text:
6 Adding a legend
The problem with FigureÂ 1 is that the individual line plots are not labelled. We would like to add a legend to the plot that maps the color to the year and adding a legend in GGPlot is awkward.Â  Generally speaking GGPlot will put a legend on the plot when something is mapped other than x or y.Â  We are going to map color.Â  To do this, we move color from being a subcomponent of the geom_line to being a mapped element of the geom_line.
plot2 = ggplot( data=(lansJanTempsDF), 
                mapping = aes(x=1:31)) +  
  geom_line( mapping=aes(y=Jan2011, color = "Jan2011") ) +
  geom_line( mapping=aes(y=Jan2012, color = "Jan2012") ) +
  geom_line( mapping=aes(y=Jan2013, color = "Jan2013") ) +
  geom_line( mapping=aes(y=Jan2014, color = "Jan2014") ) +
  geom_line( mapping=aes(y=Jan2015, color = "Jan2015") ) +
  geom_line( mapping=aes(y=Jan2016, color = "Jan2016") ) +
  labs( title="January Temperature",
        subtitle="Lansing, MI -- 2011-2016",
        x = "January Days",
        y = "temperature (F)") +
  theme_bw();
plot(plot2);
In this plot, we moved color to the mapping of the geom_line and set color to the text we want displayed in the legend.Â  This solution adds a legend with the text but the line colors are chosen by GGPlot.Â  Note: There is a way to customize these color but that is beyond the scope of this class.






FigureÂ 2: Line plots with a legend â€“ note that the legend text matches the color mappings

title: 2-09: Stacking and Mapping
text:
7 Stacking the data frame
The most common (and pretty ugly) technique used to plot multiple line plots on one canvas is to create a new data frame that has all the data you want to plot in two columns â€“ this process is often called melting or stacking the data frame.
Â 
We can use stack() to create a stacked data frame:
stackedDF = stack(lansJanTempsDF);
The stacked data frame has the same data as the original data frame but everything is put in two columns:






FigureÂ 3: A stacked dataframe of the six years of temperature data put into two columns



The stacked data frame has 186 rows (31 days * 6 years) and two columns:

column 1: combined the 6 temperature columns into one column called values
column 2: contains the names of the six temperature columns (2011 to 2016) called ind
Â 

The 6 years of data are now stacked on top of each-other with the first 31 rows containing values from 2011, the next 31 rows containing values from 2012, etcâ€¦Â  The ind columns give the year the temperatures came from.

7.1 A note from the author about stacked data frame
This author considers stacking data frames to be a bad programming practice but this practice is widely reinforced by R.Â  The reason stacking a data frame is bad is you are restructuring the data frame to meet the needs of a function.Â  But, the data frame is an object that should remain fixed.Â  The better practice is to code functions that match the structure of the data frame.Â  This is not a difficult task, but, unfortunately, this is not how R operates and there is no good way to get around stacking data frames.


7.2 Plotting the stacked data frame
With the stacked data frame, we only need one geom_line component to plot all 6 lines.Â  This works because of the color mapping.Â  The color mapping tells GGPlot to create a distinct line for each different value in the ind column â€“ and set each to a different color.Â  The ind column has 6 different value â€“ the 6 column names from the original data frame (Jan2011, Jan2012,â€¦).
Â 
The x-axis represents the days from 1 to 31.Â  We have 186 rows but every 31 rows represents a new line plot (31 * 6 = 186).Â  So, we want to repeat the values 1 to 31 six times.
Â 
The y mapping is the temperature values from the original data frame put into one long values column.
plot3 = ggplot( data=(stackedDF)) +  
  geom_line( mapping=Â«aes(x=rep(1:31, times=6)Â», y=values, color=ind) ) +
  labs( title="January Temperature",
        subtitle="Lansing, MI -- 2011-2016",
        x = "January Days",
        y = "temperature (F)") +
  theme_bw();
plot(plot3);






FigureÂ 4: Plotting using a stacked dataframe

title: 2-09: Stacking and Mapping
section: 8 Using for loops to plot 6 columns
text:
8 Using for loops to plot 6 columns
I consider using for loops to be the most robust solution because it gives you more control over what to plot and it maintains the integrity of the original data frame.Â  It is also probably the most difficult method:
  plot4 = ggplot( data=(lansJanTempsDF));  # create a canvas
  for(i in 1:ncol(lansJanTempsDF))         # add plots to canvas one at a time
  {
    # replace i by with !!(i) -- avoids Lazy Evaluation
    Â«plot4 = plot4Â» + geom_line( mapping=aes(x=1:nrow(lansJanTempsDF), 
                                             y=lansJanTempsDF[,Â«!!(i)Â»], 
                                             color=colnames(lansJanTempsDF)[Â«!!(i)Â»]) )
  }
  # add the labels and theme to the canvas
  Â«plot4 = plot4Â» + labs( title="January Temperature",
          subtitle="Lansing, MI -- 2011-2016",
          x = "January Days",
          y = "temperature (F)") +
  theme_bw();
  plot(plot4);
In this example, the for loop adds the six plot components to the plot4 canvas one at a time.Â  When mapping in a for loop, you need to replace the index variable, in this case i, with !!(i).Â  The reason is here: Extension: Lazy Evaluation
Â 
After the plot components are added, we then add the labels and theme to plot4.






FigureÂ 5: Using for loops to plot 6 column â€“ this authors believes this is the most robust solution

title: 2-09: Stacking and Mapping
text:
9 Unstacking the data frame
You can take a stacked data frame and return it to original state using unstack():
origDF = unstack(stackedDF);
And origDF looks just like the original lansJanTempDF






FigureÂ 6: Unstacking a dataframe return you to the original dataframe



Â 
Note: The stacked version of a dataframe is often called long format and the original dataframe called wide format.

title: 2-09: Stacking and Mapping
text:
10 Boxplots
A good way to visually compare the six years of January temperatures is to use a boxplot.Â  In GGPlot, the component to use is geom_boxplot. Â  For our first attempt, we will just create two boxes representing the columns Jan2011 and Jan2012.
Â 
Like all plotting components in GGPlot, geom_boxplot needs to be mapped.Â  The y-axis represents the temperatures so we can map y to the columns, Jan2011 in one box and Jan2012 in the other.
Â 
We also need to map x to something otherwise the two boxplots will appear right on top of each other (try it!). We can start by mapping the boxplot to the years they represent:
plot5 = ggplot(data=lansJanTempsDF) +
  geom_boxplot(mapping=aes(x=2011, y=Jan2011)) +
  geom_boxplot(mapping=aes(x=2012, y=Jan2012)) +
  theme_bw();
plot(plot5);  
This code successfully creates two boxplots but the x-axis is a bit weird:






FigureÂ 7: The boxes for January temperatures in 2011 and 2012



Â 
Because we used numbers to map the x-axis, GGPlot assumed a continuous and numeric x-axis.Â  But, the x-axis in a boxplot is really a discrete axis â€“ we are not plotting value in between 2011 and 2012.Â  If we want a discrete axis, then we need to put the years in quotes (i.e., make the year a string value):
  plot6 = ggplot(data=lansJanTempsDF) +
    geom_boxplot(mapping=aes(Â«x="2011"Â», y=Jan2011)) +
    geom_boxplot(mapping=aes(Â«x="2012"Â», y=Jan2012)) +
    theme_bw();
  plot(plot6);
Now, we have a discrete x-axis:






FigureÂ 8: The same boxplots with a discrete x-axis

title: 2-09: Stacking and Mapping
section: 11 Box Plots using the stacked dataframe
text:
11 Box Plots using the stacked dataframe
Just like with lines plots, there is no great way to create boxes from multiple columns in a dataframe.Â  We could plot all six columns by creating six geom_boxplot components, one for each year.Â  But, in programming, you generally do not want to repeat code â€“ this would get messy if there were 20 columns.
Â 
The most common technique used for plotting multiple columns is to use a stacked dataframe.
Â 
Using the stacked dataframe, we can plot all 6 years using one geom_boxplot component.Â  The works by mapping x to the ind column (which has the years) and mapping y to the values column (which has all the temperature values).
plot7 = ggplot(data=stackedDF) +
  geom_boxplot(mapping=aes(x=ind, y=values)) +
  theme_bw();
plot(plot7);
The x-axis of the boxplot is labelled with the names of the columns and the y-axis has the box for each year:






FigureÂ 9: Boxes for all six columns using the stacked data frame

title: 2-09: Stacking and Mapping
section: 12 Stacking a subset of the columns
text:
12 Stacking a subset of the columns
We might not want all of the data from the original dataframe. We can create a stacked dataframe that only has a subset of the columns from the original data frame.
Â 
This stacked dataframe only has the values from 2 columns, the3rd and 6th (2013 and 2016â€“ 62 values in all):
stackedDF2 = stack(lansJanTempsDF[,c(3,6)]); # 2013 and 2016
And this stacked dataframe has the values from 4 columns: the1st, 2nd, 5th, and 6th (2011, 2012, 2015, & 2016 â€“ 124 values in all):
stackedDF3 = stack(lansJanTempsDF[,c(1,2,5,6)]); # 2011, 2012, 2015, & 2016
In the Environment tab we see the two new stacked dataframes, both with 2 columns (values and ind) and 62 values (for two Januaries) and 124 values (for four Januaries)
ğŸƒ stackedDF2:   62 obs. of 2 variables
    $ values: num 25 26 29 33 35 35 ...
    $ ind    :  Factor w/ 2 levels "Jan2013",...
ğŸƒ stackedDF3:   124 obs. of 4 variables
    $ values: num 54 25 33 32 23 ...
    $ ind    :  Factor w/ 4 levels "Jan2011",...

12.1 Plotting the subset stacked dataframe
We can plot the four boxes from dataframe stackedDF3 just like we plotting all six boxes using stackedDF:
plot8 = ggplot(data=Â«stackedDF3Â») +
  geom_boxplot(mapping=aes(x=ind, y=values)) +
  theme_bw();
plot(plot8);



Plotting boxes from a stacked dataframe that has been subsetted




12.2 Plotting a subset using for loops
Again, this author believes the most robust way to plot the subset data is to use for loop.Â  Once again, this allows you to work with the original data frame â€“ there is no need to create a stacked data frame.
plot9 = ggplot( data=(lansJanTempsDF)); 
for(i in Â«c(1,2,5,6)Â»)   # cycle through the four columns
{
  ## map the column names to x and the column values to y
  plot9 = plot9 + geom_boxplot(mapping=aes(x=colnames(lansJanTempsDF)[!!(i)], 
                                            y=lansJanTempsDF[,!!(i)] ))
}
plot9 = plot9 + theme_bw();
plot(plot9);
In this code,

the for loops only cycles through the four columns we want to plot c(1,2,5,6).Â 
x is mapped to the subsetted column name
y is mapped to the subsetted column values
Â 







FigureÂ 10: Using for loops to create a boxplot of four of the columns from the temperature data frame

title: 2-09: Stacking and Mapping
section: 13 Saving data frames to one object
text:
13 Saving data frames to one object
In this lesson, we created four data frames:

lansJanTempsDF: the original data frame
stackedDF: a stacked version of the full data frame
stackedDF2: a stacked version of columns 3 and 6 only
stackedDF3: a stacked version of columns 1, 3, 5, and 6
Â 

We are going to use these data frames in the next lesson.Â  In the next lesson, we could just reopen the lansingJanTempsFixed.csv file, save the data to a data frame and then create the stacked dataframes.Â  But, since we have already done that work, it would be easier to pass the data frames from this lesson to the next lesson.
Â 
We will create one object that holds all four data frame using list().Â  The object is a List object (we will be talking a lot more about List object in the next few lessons):
temperatureDFs= list("origDF" = lansJanTempsDF,
                     "stackedDF" = stackedDF,
                     "stackDF_3_6" = stackedDF2,
                     "stackedDF_1_2_5_6" = stackedDF3);
The value in quotes is the name of the object â€“ you can choose the name but you should use variable naming conventions.
Â 
temperatureDFs appear in the Environment as a List object with four data frames inside it.Â  We can view the data frames in the list by clicking on the arrow in the Environment tab or double-clicking on temperatureDFs to see it in a viewer tab:






FigureÂ 11: The List object in the Environment and the viewer tab




13.1 Saving the List object to a file
We want to use the List object with four data frames in the next lesson.Â  To do this, we need to save the List to a file â€“ a file we will open in the next lesson:
save(temperatureDFs, file = "data/tempDFs.rdata");
There should now be a file named tempDFs.rdata in the data folder of your Project that contains temperatureDFs.

title: 2-09: Stacking and Mapping
text:
15 Extension: Lazy Evaluation
This is probably the one programming topic that has caused the most agony in this authors life as it is unintuitive and happens unexpectedly in many programming languagesâ€¦
Â 
There are 7 columns in lansJanTempsDF, which means the for loop will cycle 7 times. Each time with a different value for i (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7).
for(i in 1:ncol(lansJanTempsDF))         # add plots to canvas one at a time
{
  plot4 = plot4 + geom_line( mapping=aes(x=1:nrow(lansJanTempsDF), 
                                         y=lansJanTempsDF[,i], 
                                         color=colnames(lansJanTempsDF)[i]) )
}
However, if you execute the code above you will only see one plot â€“ the plot for the seventh cycle (when i=7). Actually, the seventh plot got plotted seven times but they overlap each other so you only see one.
Â 
The reason this happens is that R, in the background, will first stack up the code from all seven cycles of the for loop like this:
plot4 = plot4 + geom_line( mapping=aes(x=1:nrow(lansJanTempsDF), 
                                         y=lansJanTempsDF[,Â«iÂ»], 
                                         color=colnames(lansJanTempsDF)[Â«iÂ»])
plot4 = plot4 + geom_line( mapping=aes(x=1:nrow(lansJanTempsDF), 
                                         y=lansJanTempsDF[,Â«iÂ»], 
                                         color=colnames(lansJanTempsDF)[Â«iÂ»])
plot4 = plot4 + geom_line( mapping=aes(x=1:nrow(lansJanTempsDF), 
                                         y=lansJanTempsDF[,Â«iÂ»], 
                                         color=colnames(lansJanTempsDF)[Â«iÂ»])
... (4 more) ...
And then execute each command in the stack. This happens all the time when programming for loops and it is normally not an issue. Except, in this case, R does not realize that i is the index variable. R assumes that i=7 because that is the value of i at the end of the for loop (i.e., after the seventh cycle). So, R replaces i with 7 for every command. This is called Lazy Evaluation and I cannot explain why it happens here, but I can say that I have experienced it many times in many programming languages in my career.
Â 
!!() is a function that forces R to immediately evaluate what is inside the parentheses (i.e., before R stacks the commands). This means the stacked commands will look like this and execute properly:
plot4 = plot4 + geom_line( mapping=aes(x=1:nrow(lansJanTempsDF), 
                                         y=lansJanTempsDF[,Â«1Â»], 
                                         color=colnames(lansJanTempsDF)[Â«1Â»])
plot4 = plot4 + geom_line( mapping=aes(x=1:nrow(lansJanTempsDF), 
                                         y=lansJanTempsDF[,Â«2Â»], 
                                         color=colnames(lansJanTempsDF)[Â«2Â»])
plot4 = plot4 + geom_line( mapping=aes(x=1:nrow(lansJanTempsDF), 
                                         y=lansJanTempsDF[,Â«3Â»], 
                                         color=colnames(lansJanTempsDF)[Â«3Â»])
... (4 more) ...

title: 2-11: Objects and Attributes

title: 2-11: Objects and Attributes
text:
3 Terminology
This lesson requires the use of terminology that has been inconsistently used in R or has morphed in meaning throughout the years, so you will find different definitions online.Â  In general, I will be using the terminology from the 2nd edition of Hadley Wickhamâ€™s Advanced R book and mention places where there is commonly used terminology that is different.

title: 2-11: Objects and Attributes
text:
4 Objects and Variables
In the programming world, anything stored in memory that has a value (or multiple values) associated with it is called a variable.Â  This terms gets a bit confusing because values that do not change are still called variables (sometimes called constant variables).Â  Also, variables has different meanings in different fields from mathematics to science to statistics.Â  Perhaps, for this reason, R tends to use the term object to define anything that has a name and stores values. That means that, in R, everything in the Environment tab in RStudio is an object.
Â 
Broadly speaking, in R there are two types of objects: Atomic Vectors (covered in this lesson) and Lists (covered in the next lesson).Â 

4.1 Atomic vectors and Lists
Atomic vectors are objects that hold values of the same type (e.g., numeric, string).Â  In other words, atomic vectors are just vectors. However, in R, you will get often get error messages that refer to an â€œatomic vectorâ€ (FigureÂ 6).
Â 
Anything you create with c() is an atomic vector and atomic vectors can have dimensions â€“ a 2D atomic vector is called a matrix and a 3D atomic vector is called an array.


4.2 Atomic vectors vs List
Whereas atomic vectors hold values, a List is an object that holds other objects â€“ including other Lists.
Â 
A data frame is an example of a List where each column is an atomic vector â€“ and each column has the same number of values.


4.3 Folder and file analogy for Lists and atomic vectors
Lists and Atomic Vectors functionally play the same role as folder and files on your computer.Â  Folders are used to create a tree-like structure for information on your computer. Folders contain folders and files (the tree-like structure), folders do not directly contain information.Â  It is the files that contains the information â€“ and files are always at the end of the tree (a file cannot contain another folder or file).
Â 
Lists are the folders of the R world â€“ they create a tree-like structure for information.Â  Lists can contain other Lists or Atomic Vector.Â  The Atomic Vector are the files â€“ they contain information and are always at the end of the tree (Atomic Vector cannot contain Lists nor other atomic vectors).
Â 
A data frame is a type of List (folder) that contains multiple columns/Atomic Vectors (files) of the same size.
Â 
Note: Atomic vectors are often referred to as homogeneous objects and Lists are often referred to as heterogeneous objects, but I believe these terms are not helpful as they create a false distinction between Lists and atomic vectors.

title: 2-11: Objects and Attributes
section: 5 The simplest object in R: the vector
text:
5 The simplest object in R: the vector
Because R is a programming language designed to work with data, the vector represents the most basic object in R.Â  Note: This is different from most programming languages where a single named value is the most basic object.
Â 
A vector is a named object that hold values of the same type (or class) â€“ usually strings or numeric.
Â 
Even a single value is put into a vector.Â  Setting a variable to one value creates a one-value vector:
temperature = 80; # a vector, temperature, with one value, 80
The fact that temperature is a vector with one value is not shown in the Environment but it is shown in the Console with the [1]:
> temperature
[1] 80
This code creates a vector named JulyTemps with eight numeric values:
JulyTemps = c(90, 88, 86, 77,81, 83, 80, 80);
And, the Environment shows that it is a numeric (num) vector with eight values [1:8]:
JulyTemps num [1:8] 90 88 86 ...

5.1 Types of vector
There are six basic types/classes of vectors in R:

characters (strings)
numeric (decimal numbers)
integers (numbers without decimals)
complex (numbers with real and imaginary parts â€“ these are not covered in this class)
Boolean/logical (TRUE/FALSE values)
raw (hold bytes â€“ rarely used and are not covered in this class)
Â 

We have mentioned character and numeric vectors multiple times in previous lessons.Â  We are going to look a little deeper into integer and Boolean vectors.


5.2 Integer vectors
Integer vectors can be useful when you need counting values because integer values take up less space in memory and can be processed faster than numeric (i.e., decimal) vectors.
Â 
The issue is that, R will often coerce integer vectors to numeric vectors, effectively taking away the memory and speed advantages.
Â 
Letâ€™s create an integer vector:
intValues = as.integer(c(3,4,5));
And then add 1 :
intValues2 = intValues + 1;
In the Environment we see that intValues is an integer vector but intValues2 is numeric:
intValues:    int [1:3] 3 4 5
intValues2:   num [1:3] 4 5 6
If we want the results to be an integer, then we need to declare 1 as an integer:
intValues3 = intValues + as.integer(1);
Now, R will see the results as integers:
intValues3: int [1:3] 4 5 6
Extension: rounding functions in R


5.3 A Boolean/logical vector (TRUE/FALSE values)
We have not talked much about Boolean vectors but they are useful in programming because they are fast as they only have two possible values: TRUE and FALSE.Â  Note: It is bad programming practice (and potentially dangerous) to use T and F to represent TRUE and FALSE.
Â 
There are two general ways to create a Boolean vector: manually or with a conditional statement

5.3.1 Manually create a Boolean vector
We can use c() to create a vector with Boolean values.Â  Letâ€™s create a vector that tells whether it rained on the eight days in JulyTemps:
rainyDaysInJuly = c(FALSE, FALSE, TRUE, FALSE, FALSE, TRUE, TRUE, FALSE);
In the Environment, rainyDaysInJuly is given as a logi, which stands for logical â€“ which is just another name for Boolean:
rainyDaysInJuly: logi [1:8] FALSE FALSE TRUE ...
and we can check which values are TRUE using which():
which(rainyDaysInJuly)
[1] 3 5 6


5.3.2 Conditional statements create a Boolean vector
A conditional statement always creates a Boolean vector.Â  We typically used conditional statements in if() statements:
for(i in 1:length(JulyTemps))
{
  # Output Boolean value instead of executing the if() statement
  #  if(JulyTemps[i] > 85)
  cat("day", i, (JulyTemps[i] > 85), "\n");
}    
The output from the above for loop is:
day 1 TRUE 
day 2 TRUE 
day 3 TRUE 
day 4 FALSE 
day 5 FALSE 
day 6 FALSE 
day 7 FALSE 
day 8 FALSE 
This means that the first three days in JulyTemps were more than 85, the rest were less than or equal to 85.
Â 
We could also save Boolean results to a vector.Â  (JulyTemps > 85) instructs R to check the 8 values in JulyTemps against the number 85:
hotterThan85 = (JulyTemps > 85);
And the answer is given as a Boolean vector:
> hotterThan85
[1]  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE

title: 2-11: Objects and Attributes
text:
6 Attributes of a objects
Attributes is a very broad term in R.Â  All objects can have attributes and there are two distinct types of attributes in R.
Â 
1) Attributes that are properties of the object â€“ these are defined by R and they include:

names: names for the values inside an object â€“ not to be confused with the name of the object
class: the type of object is it (numeric, booleanâ€¦)
dim: dimension â€“ this is how you create a 2D matrix, 3D array, or higher dimension arrays

Â 
2) Attributes that act as metadata for the object.Â  These attributes are defined by the user and are analogous to comments in a script.
Â 
Attributes can be confusing because there is not a consistent way to apply or view them in R.Â  In this lesson, we will look at attributes on vectors and next lesson look at attributes on Lists.

title: 2-11: Objects and Attributes
text:
7 names attribute
All objects have a name and they can be assigned an attribute called names.Â  The name of the object and the names attribute are two different things. The attribute names refers to names given to the values within the object and are assigned using the names() function.
Â 
Letâ€™s first create a copy of our JulyTemps vector:
JulyTempsNamed = JulyTemps;
And we will use names() to give the date to each temperature value:
names(JulyTempsNamed) = c("July22", "July23", "July24", "July25",
                          "July26", "July27", "July28", "July29");
JulyTempsNamed is called a Named vector in the Environment and the names are given in the Console:
JulyTempsNames:  Named num [1:8] 90 88 86 77...
And in the Console, JulyTempsNamed has two rows, the first contains the names and the second contains the values:
> JulyTempsNamed
July22 July23 July24 July25 July26 July27 July28 July29 
    90     88     86     77     81     83     80     80

7.1 Subsetting named values with square brackets [ ]
The main advantage to naming vectors is that you can use the names to subset the value within the object.
Â 
To get the second value in JulyTempsNamed, you can subset with the position (2) or the name (July23):



> JulyTempsNamed[2]
July23 
    88 
> JulyTempsNamed["July23"]
July23 
    88 


FigureÂ 1: Subsetting a named vector with the position and the name â€“ the results are the same



You can subset multiple values by position or name:
> JulyTempsNamed[c(2,4,6)]
July23 July25 July27 
    88     77     83 
> JulyTempsNamed[c("July23", "July25", "July27")]
July23 July25 July27 
    88     77     83 
From a functional perspective, named values and unnamed values will work exactly the same in any computation.Â  The difference between the two is only how they are displayed and how they can be referenced.Â  Here we subtract all values in JulyTempsNamed by 20:



> JulyTempsNamed - 20
July22 July23 July24 July25 July26 July27 July28 July29 
    70     68     66     57     61     63     60     60 


FigureÂ 2: You can do mathematics on named values just like unnamed values





7.2 Subsetting named values with double-square brackets [[ ]]
You can also subset a named vector with double square brackets [[Â  ]] and you will just get the value (without the name):



> JulyTempsNamed[[2]]
[1] 88
> JulyTempsNamed[["July23"]]
[1] 88


FigureÂ 3: Using double brackets to subset named vectors will give you just the value



This is generally not recommended because you cannot select multiple elements using [[ ]]



> JulyTempsNamed[2:4]
July23 July24 July25 
    88     86     77 
> JulyTempsNamed[[2:4]]
Error in JulyTempsNamed[[2:4]] : 
  attempt to select more than one element in vectorIndex


FigureÂ 4: using single brackets and double brackets to subset multiple values in a vector



Note: element here means the same as values (so, theÂ  8 elements in JulyTempsNamed are the eight values)

title: 2-11: Objects and Attributes
text:
8 dimension (dim) attribute
When you create a vector using c(), you are creating an object that, functionally, has one dimension.Â  This is why you can subset values in JulyTemps using their position within the vector (FigureÂ 1).
Â 
However, data is sometimes best represented in multiple dimensions â€“ for instance you might have temperatures that are stored by both location and date.

8.1 Multidimensional objects
We can use dim() to add more dimensions to a vector.
Â 
We are going to make a two-dimensional vector (also called a matrix or a 2D array) using JulyTemps.Â  First, we will create a copy of JulyTemps and then set the dimensions of the copy to two values (4 and 2).Â  Those two dimension values (which can be thought of as 4 rows and 2 columns) must multiply to the number of values in the vector (8).
JulyTemps2D = July Temps;
dim(JulyTemps2D) = c(4,2);
The Environment and Console reflect the dimensions in JulyTemps2D:
> JulyTemps2D
     [,1] [,2]
[1,]   90   81
[2,]   88   83
[3,]   86   80
[4,]   77   80



JulyTemps2D: num [1:4, 1:2] 90 88 86 77...


FigureÂ 5: Displaying a 2D value in the Console and the Environment



Now we have a 2D object that can be subsetted using the [ , ] operator (which can be though of as a dimensional subset operator):
> JulyTemps2D[3,2]
[1] 80
We could create a three-dimensional object (called a 3D array) by setting the dimensions to three values.Â  The numbers still need to multiply to 8:
JulyTemps3D = JulyTemps;
dim(JulyTemps3D) = c(2,2,2); # each dimension has length of 2
> JulyTemps3D[1,2,2]
[1] 80
Note: You can declare a one-dimensional vector (also called a 1D array).Â  I do not know if there is a practical reason to do this since vectors functionally operate as 1D objects:
JulyTemps1D = JulyTemps;
dim(JulyTemps1D) = c(8);


8.2 accessing rows and columns in matrices
Letâ€™s take the 2D matrix we created and add names for the rows and columns using rownames() and colnames():
JulyTemps2DNamed = JulyTemps2D;
rownames(JulyTemps2DNamed) = paste("date", 1:4, sep="");
colnames(JulyTemps2DNamed) = c("location1", "location2");
And we can see the names in the Console:
> JulyTemps2DNamed
      location1 location2
date1        90        81
date2        88        83
date3        86        80
date4        77        80
We can now access values in the matrix by name or position using the dimensional operator:
> JulyTemps2DNamed[3,2]
[1] 80
> JulyTemps2DNamed["date3","location2"]
[1] 80
And we can access whole rows or columns by leaving the other blank:
> JulyTemps2DNamed[3,]
location1 location2 
       86        80 
> JulyTemps2DNamed[,2]
date1 date2 date3 date4 
   81    83    80    80 
> JulyTemps2DNamed[,"location2"]
date1 date2 date3 date4 
   81    83    80    80 


8.3 matrices are vectors
The [ , ] operator is really the same thing as the [ ] operator.Â  The difference is that [ , ] is used for 2D objects (matrices) whereas [ ] is used for 1D objects (vectors).
Â 
You can use the 1D operator on a matrix â€“ [ ] will flatten the matrix to one dimensional vector:
> JulyTemps2DNamed[1:8]
[1] 90 88 86 77 81 83 80 80

> JulyTemps2DNamed[5]
[1] 81


8.4 The $ operator
You cannot use $ to subset any Atomic Vector (vector, matrix, or array). You will get the $ operator is invalid for atomic vectors error:



> JulyTemps2DNamed$col2
Error in JulyTemps2DNamed$col2 : $ operator is invalid for atomic vectors


FigureÂ 6: R does not allow use of $ operator on vectors

title: 2-11: Objects and Attributes
text:
9 class attribute and typeof()
class() is a function that allows you to either view or set the class of an object (i.e., change a numeric vector to a character vector).Â  You should never use class() to changes the class of an object, instead use a specialized function like as.character().
Â 
Using class() to get the class of an object will produces inconsistent results.Â  Using class on an object will return the value type if the vector has no dimensions set, and will return the object type if there are dimensions set:
> class(JulyTemps2D)
[1] "matrix" "array" 
> class(JulyTemps)
[1] "numeric"
Instead of class, you should use typeof(). It will always give you the class of the values:
> typeof(JulyTemps2D)
[1] "double"
> typeof(JulyTemps)
[1] "double"
Note: double means the values are numeric.Â  In other programming languages (especially older ones), there is a corresponding single class that does not exist in R.

title: 2-11: Objects and Attributes
text:
10 Other attributes (metadata or comments)
You can create any attribute you want and add it an object using attr().Â  We are going to add two attributes using attr() to a copy of JulyTemps2DNamed.Â  The attributes will be named timeChecked and unit and they will be set to noon and Fahrenheit:
JulyTemps2DNamed_2 = JulyTemps2DNamed;
attr(JulyTemps2DNamed_2, "timeChecked") = "noon";
attr(JulyTemps2DNamed_2, "unit") = "Fahrenheit";
note: while not enforced, attribute names should follow variable variable naming conventions
Â 
We can also use attr() to get the attributes of an object:
> attr(JulyTempsNamed_2, "timeChecked")
[1] "noon"
> attr(JulyTempsNamed_2, "unit")
[1] "Fahrenheit"
User-defined attributes should be treated as comments or metadata.Â  Attributes give information that might interest the user of your script but attributes should not be a functional part of the script.Â 

10.1 Viewing all attributes
If you view a object in the Console, the user-defined attributes will be displayed:
> JulyTemps2DNamed_2
      location1 location2
date1        90        81
date2        88        83
date3        86        80
date4        77        80
attr(,"timeChecked")
[1] "noon"
attr(,"unit")
[1] "Fahrenheit"
For a more robust view of the attributes in an object, you can use attributes():
> attributes(JulyTemps2DNamed_2)
$dim
[1] 4 2
$dimnames
$dimnames[[1]]
[1] "date1" "date2" "date3" "date4"
$dimnames[[2]]
[1] "location1" "location2"

$timeChecked
[1] "noon"
$unit
[1] "Fahrenheit"
Note: dimnames is a property attribute that was set when you set the row and column names

text:
12 Extension: rounding functions in R
There are three rounding functions in R:

round() Â  # rounds to nearest integer (5.3 become 5 and 5.7 becomes 6)
floor() # drops the decimal (both 5.3 and 5.7 become 5)
ceiling()Â  # increase decimal number to next integerÂ  (both 5.3 and 5.7 become 6)
Â 

Even though these function create integer-like values, R will still see the values as numeric:
> a = c(2.5, 3.6, -1.3)
> b = round(a)
> b
[1]  2  4 -1
> class(b)
[1] "numeric"
If you actually want integer values, then you need to to convert the vector to an integer:
> b = as.integer(b)
> b
[1]  2  4 -1
> class(b)
[1] "integer"
Integer values have a speed advantage over numeric values, which you will notice if you are processing 100,000 values.

title: 2-13: Breakpoints
text:
3 Debugging your code
One of the most powerful debugging tools in any programming language, and a staple of all professional programmers, is the breakpoint.Â  Breakpoints allows you to pause the execution of your script at a specific line or command.Â  While paused, you can look at the Environment, enter commands in the Console, or move through your script one command at a time. This is a very useful tool when debugging for loop that and cycling thousands of times.
Â 
The implementation of breakpoints in R is far less robust than most programming languages. Even with this limitation, breakpoints are still a useful debugging tool in R.

title: 2-13: Breakpoints
text:
4 Setting up a breakpoint
A breakpoint is like a pause button in the execution your script and there are multiple ways to set a breakpoint.Â In this lesson we will focus on using the Rstudio interface to set a breakpoint. In RStudio, you set a breakpoint by clicking to the left of the line number â€“ this is called the gutter area.Â  A red dot representing the breakpoint appears in the gutter area.Â  Clicking again will get rid of the breakpoint.






FigureÂ 1: Breakpoint (red dot) set on line 8



When you Source your code, the script will execute up to, but not including, the line with the breakpoint.Â  Your script is now paused at the line with a breakpoint, and you are in debug mode, which R calls Browse mode (FigureÂ 2).
Â 
Note: A breakpoint only works when you Source your script.Â  It will not work if you use Run to execute lines of code.

4.1 Debug Mode
There are 4 things in RStudio that will indicate you are in debug mode:

A green arrow will appear at the code line the script is paused at â€“ the green arrow shows you the line that will be executed next
Breakpoint controls will appear in the Console tab
The Console will indicate it is in browse modeÂ  with > Browse

The number (in this case, 1) is telling you how many levels deep you are.Â  The functionality of this number has changed in recent versions of RStudio and this author is still not quite sure what it represents.

A traceback window will appear at the bottom of the Environment tab

traceback is a more advanced debugging tool that we will not get into in this lesson


Â 






FigureÂ 2: Sourcing a script with a breakpoint puts it into debug mode

title: 2-13: Breakpoints
text:
5 Using the Browse in breakpoint
In this lesson I will put breakpoint instructions in comments like this so you can follow along:
## In the lesson script:
##Â Â Â  Place a breakpoint at line 8 in the lessonâ€™s script and click Source
8 diffTemp = highTemps - lowTemps;
In FigureÂ 2, the script is currently paused at line 8, this means all commands in lines 1-7 have been executed.Â  In the Environment you can see weatherData, highTemps, and lowTemps, which were added between lines 1-7.
weatherData   366 obs. of 24 variables
highTemps     int [1:366] 29 35 33 27 29...
lowTemps      int [1:366] 24 28 25 7 8 20...
When in debug mode, you can enter commands in the Console.Â  With these commands you can do things like view values in or execute functions on a vector:
Browse[1]> highTemps[1:20]
[1] 29 35 33 27 29 36 42 39 42 38 16 23 18 34 42 33 26 15 21 22
Browse[1]> max(highTemps)
[1] 94
Or, you can create a new variable and add it to the Environment:
Browse[1]> highTemp_C = (5/9)*(highTemps-32)
Browse[1]>
highTemp_C     num [1:366] -1.667 1.667 0.556 -2.778...

title: 2-13: Breakpoints
section: 6 Moving through code in debug (browse) mode
text:
6 Moving through code in debug (browse) mode
When your script arrives at a breakpoint (FigureÂ 2) , five buttons to control the flow of your script appear in the Console tab:
1) Next: executes the command at the green arrow (in other debuggers, this is often called Step Over)
2) Step In: moves into a function
3) Step Out: completes a for loop or function
4) Continue: unpauses the execution of the script (like hitting the Play button when a video is paused)
5) Stop: quits the script (no more code is executed)
Â 
When in debug mode you should only use the buttons to control the flow of your script.Â  In debug mode, clicking Source will cause problems with your script. Extension: Clicking Source in debug mode (read next section on Stop first).






FigureÂ 3: The five breakpoint control in debug mode




6.1 Stop
Clicking Stop will take R out of debug mode and end the execution of the script.Â  In other words, no more commands in the script will be executed and all the components of debug mode (FigureÂ 2) will go away.
Â 
When you click Stop, Q is put in the Console. Q is the command to quit debug mode. You could directly type Q instead of clicking Stop.






FigureÂ 4: Stopping debug mode





6.2 Continue to next Breakpoint
## In the lesson script:
## Add a second breakpoint on line 17 (so, now we have breakpoints at lines 8 and 17) and click Source
17 sunsetTimes_12Hour = c();
The script will pause at the first breakpoint (line 8).Â  If you click Continue, the script will unpause and continue executing the script until the next breakpoint is reached on line 17 and pause there (green arrow).Â  Between the first and second pause, lines 9-17 are executed and the results of these commands are in the Environment.
Â 
In Console, the Continue command is c.






FigureÂ 5: Continue takes the script to the next breakpoint (if there is another one)





6.3 Continue to end of script
After line 17 there are no more breakpoints, so if you click Continue again, the rest of the script will be executed and you will be taken out of debug mode.






FigureÂ 6: Clicking Continue when there are no more breakpoint executes the rest of the script





6.4 breakpoint inside for loop
## In lesson script:
##Â Â  Remove the breakpoints at lines 9 and 18
##Â Â  Add a breakpoint at line 24 (inside the for loop)
24 sunsetTimes_12Hour[i] = convertTime(sunsetTimes[i]);
If you put a breakpoint inside a for loop then Continue will stop at the breakpoint every cycle of the for loop.Â In FigureÂ 7 I clicked Continue 20 time and the for loop has cycled 20 times (and i = 20)






FigureÂ 7: Continue clicked 20 times (note: i=20) with a breakpoint inside the for loop





6.5 Next
## In lesson script:
##Â Â  Remove breakpoint on line 24
##Â Â  Add a breakpoint on line 14
14 sunsetTimes = weatherData$sunset;
If we Source the script, the code up until line 13 will execute and line 14 will have a green arrow in the gutter.
Â 
We can now execute one command at a time using Next.
Â 
Clicking Next executes the command on line 14 and moves the green arrow to the next command on line 15.
Â 
So, sunsetTimes is created and put in the Environment and line 15, which creates sunriseTimes, is highlighted with the green arrow..






FigureÂ 8: Clicking Next executes the command at the green arrow and moves the green arrow to the next command





6.6 Multiple Commands on one line
## In lesson script:
## Â  Click Next until you get to line 20
20 testCommand1=1; testCommand2=2; testCommand3=3;
Next does not execute lines, Next executes commands.Â  Lines 17 and 18 have one command each but line 20 has 3 commands. If there are multiple commands on one line then Next will execute them one at a time and the debugger will highlight the current command.






FigureÂ 9: Only the current command is highlighted â€“ clicking Next moves through the commands on the line.

title: 2-13: Breakpoints
text:
7 Debugging in a for loop
## In lesson script:
##Â Â  Click Next until you get to line 22
22 for(i in 1:length(sunsetTimes))
When the green arrow gets to a for loop, RStudio will highlight the whole for loop:






FigureÂ 10: Highlighting the whole for loop in debug mode



Â 
Clicking Next executes the initialization command for the for loop:
for(i in 1:length(sunsetTimes))
In this initialization command:

the variable i is set to 1
a rule is given for how i changes each time the for loop cycles (i.e., i increases by 1)
the cycles end when i is equal to sunsetTime

Â 
The initialization command of a for loop executes once whereas everything inside the for loop executes once per cycle of the for loop.
Â 
After the initialization command is executed, Next will move the control inside the for loop:






FigureÂ 11: After executing the initialization command, the green arrow moves inside the for loop



If you keep clicking Next and debug mode will go through each command in the for loop for each cycle of the for loop

7.1 Step Out of the for loop
If you are inside a for loop and want to finish executing the whole for loop (i.e., complete every cycle of the loop), you can click Step Out.Â  This will execute the rest of the for loop and put the control on the next command as long as you have no breakpoints in the for loop.






FigureÂ 12: Clicking Step Out will execute the rest of the for loop and move control to the next command



Note: If you have a breakpoint inside the for loop then Step Out will just execute to the breakpoint â€“ similar to Continue (FigureÂ 5).


7.2 Conditional breakpoints
## In lesson script:
##Â Â  Click Stop
##Â Â  Add breakpoint on line 29 and Source script
27  if(i == 200)  # acts as conditional breakpoint
28  {
29    NULL;   # this line functionally does nothing
30  }
A for loop can easily run thousands or millions of times and you often only want a breakpoint on a specific cycle of the for loop.Â  In most programming language, you can attach a condition to the breakpoint so that the breakpoint only activates when specified.
Â 
In R, you need to manually code this condition.Â  You can pause at a specific cycle of the for loop using an if statement:
if(i == 200)    # acts as conditional breakpoint
{
  NULL;  # this line functionally does nothing
}
The breakpoint needs to be put inside the codeblock attached to the if statement. Inside the codeblock is a NULL command â€“ meaning it does nothing (it is only there to provide a space for the breakpoint).
Â 
With the breakpoint on line 29, the script will pause on the 200th cycle of the for loop:






FigureÂ 13: Using an if statement as a conditional breakpoint inside a for loop



Â 
Or, if you put a a breakpoint at line 33, you can conditionally break on a value being used in the for loop:
if(sunsetTimes[i] == 2000)
{
  NULL; 
}
The script will pause on the 141st cycle of the for loop, which represents the first day that sunset is at exactly 8:00pm (2000 hours)






FigureÂ 14: Conditional breakpoint based on a variable used in the for loop

title: 2-13: Breakpoints
text:
8 If-else statements
## In lesson script:
##Â Â  Remove breakpoint on line 33
##Â Â  Add a breakpoint on line 38
38 if(testCommand3 == 1) # FALSE
Similar to the initialization of for loops, the code inside the parentheses of if-else statements is a command.Â  The command, which is a conditional statements, outputs a Boolean (TRUE/FALSE) value that is used to determined if the codeblock gets executed.
Â 
When you set a breakpoint at the if() line, the whole if-else is highlighted in RStudio when the code is stopped at the line.Â 






FigureÂ 15: Debug mode when the control is at the beginning of an if-else structure



As you click Next, the control (green arrow) will either:

move to the next conditional statement (if the current conditional statement is FALSE)
move inside the codeblock (if the current conditional statement is TRUE)

Â 
The following lines are not executed in an if-else structure and ill be skipped over in debug mode:

codeblocks attached to FALSE conditional statements
else statements that were preceded by a TRUE conditional statement

the codeblock attached to these else statements will also not be executed

title: 2-13: Breakpoints
text:
9 Debugging within functions (Step In)
Inside the for loop on lines 24 and 25, we call convertTime twice.Â  convertTime is a function inside debugTest.R.Â  If you click Next while on line 24, then the whole line is executed, along with the convertTime function, and control will go to the next line.
Â 
You can debug inside the convertTime function by clicking Step-In while on the lines with the function â€“ this will move control to the function and the whole function will be highlighted:






FigureÂ 16: After clicking Step-In on line 24, control is moved to the function



Step-in works whether the function is inside the same script or in another script.Â  However, Step-in will not work if the function is inside a package â€“ for packages that we need to use trace() (next lesson).

9.1 Executing command within the function
Once inside the function you can use the debug buttons like before. Next will execute one command at a time inside the function.Â  Step Out will complete the whole function and return to the next command in the main script.

title: 2-13: Breakpoints
text:
10 Other ways to add breakpoints
This lesson only goes through the fundamentals of breakpoints and debugging that apply to just about any programming language.Â  However, the methods in this lesson will not work for adding breakpoints to script files outside of your main script (the one you Source) or functions within packages.Â  Other strategies are needed to add breakpoints to these location.
Â 
The functions that can add breakpoints to external script files and packages are (in order of complexity) are:

browser()
debugonce()
debug()
trace()

Â 
In the next lesson, we will look at these debug commands.

12 Extension: Clicking Source in debug mode
Sourcing a script when it is in debug mode is never a good idea. When you click Source while in debug mode, you are creating a new instance of your script with all the breakpoints attached. What this effectively means is that you are in multiple debug modes for the same script. When you want to quit debug mode, you have to quit for each instance. Something like this:

13 Extension: Modifying breakpoints in debug mode
Breakpoints added in debug mode will not work until the next time the script is Sourced. You will see an outlined red dot and a message about how breakpoints will not be active.






FigureÂ 18: Adding a breakpoint on line 18 while in debug mode



If you remove a breakpoint in debug mode, the red dot will disappear but the breakpoint remains in effect until you exit debug mode.

text:
14 Extension: Removing all breakpoints
Sometimes breakpoints will not go away even after you click to remove the red dot. This is a bug in RStudio. To fix this you can tell RStudio to remove all breakpoints Menu -> Debug -> Remove All
Â 
If the problem persists, you will need to close and reopen RStudio.
